text: From the can poured into snifter. Pours clear amber with quickly vanishing white head. Nose of ripe tropical fruits, malt. Taste pine, Passion fruit, slightly alcoholic. Finish is dry, herbal to fruity...

On tap @ Umami Burger, NYC. A near clear mild amber one, only a little lacing islandy off-white head on the top. Mildish nose. Some peach sweetness, candy and not too much more. Its also really mild in the taste. Thin oily in the mouth and its just about average on the carbonation. A bit mineralish and dry in a way. Mild red fruits and some peach. A bit dull, but tasty. Works with the burger! 21.06.2015
Pouring a cognac amber. Aromas of caramel, toast, and faint liqueur. Bready malt character evident. Nice mouthfeel. More of an amber than a cream ale IMHO.

Appearance: clear medium amber with one fat finger of fluffy ivory head, good retention and moderate lacing. (4/5) Aroma: floral, caramel, resin. (7/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter. (7/10) Palate: medium body, moderate carbonation, off-dry medium bitter finish. (4/5)

Definitely one of the best Cream Ales Ive ever had. Scratch, that, I checked: its the best example of the style Ive ever had. Mostly because of the larger-than-normal hop presence, of course. Unlike most Cream Ales, this one has a significant hop presence, pretty evenly balanced against the sweet malt in intensity. Not a whole lot happening, but very easy drinking. Definitely would not say no to another. (14/20)

7/10 #ryansbooze ryansbooze.com
Can at home. Amber colour, offwhite creamy head. Sweet caramel malty, dry and resinous hops, a bit grassy, medium bitter. Medium carbonated, medium bodied.

This poured an amber color with a white head. The aroma is floral and contains some vanilla, caramel, and light citrus. The flavor is slightly bitter but malty with some bitter lemon notes, grassy notes as well, and a bit of caramel. This is more bitter than I was expecting which Im ok with. Overall a decent beer for a usually boring style. Get you some sweet action tonight ;)

Clear , amber color. Medium sized, white head. Malt , caramel, grass and citrus in aroma. Sweet, malty beginning and hoppy , bitter finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Amber color with a tall, lasting foamy beige colored head. Aromas of caramel, pale malt, some light fruit and hints of dry floral hops. Light caramel malt flavors, perhaps a bit earthy. Mild bitterness throughout. Reminds me of an ESB. 4/12
Color cobrizo, espuma cremosa aunque poco duradera. Aroma a pomelo, resinas y pan. En boca tiene cuerpo y suavidad, con cierto equilibrio entre las maltas y los lúpulos. Buena.

Draft @ Brouwcafé de Molen. Pours a clear golden beer with a medium sized, bright white head on top. Aroma has a hint of red fruits, some bready yeast, some apples and a hint of grapefruit. Flavor is a bit bland and rather boring, mild on the bitterness, some white fruits and pinch of zest in there. Medium high in carbonation, makes me burp like a... and aftertaste is medium bittersweet. Meh..nothing new to see here, just ok.

Here we take a whack at the ignoble cream ale! However, it is a fine example of the form so we were spared a trip down vomitus lane. It pours a surprisingly cloudy amber orange with a thin head and a sweet vanillay scent. The taste is a nice balance of a malty/hoppy body with a fair (but not cloying) dose of vanilla extracty sweetness. Good for the wind down from a flurry of cleaning activity as the night descends into the realm of the senses.

Deep gold pour with clingy white head. Aroma is fruity and resiny. Flavor is sweet malt with some floral/fruity hops. Medium bodied with a solid bitter finish. This beer could give cream ales a good name:)
can. Decent. Not too memorable but balanced and easy drinking. Both sweet and bitter.

Barwa bursztynowa. Zapach silnie słodowy, lekko ciasteczkowy z odrobiną wanilii i chmielowe cytrusy. Smak podobny, acz chmiele bardziej intensywne - cytrusowo-trawiaste. Słodowa podstawa z wyraźnym karmelem.
Tap clear amber colour with medium white head.Aroma is smooth and creamy with taste of strawberrys and malt,light body and sweet light finish.
From tap at Taphouse. A clear amber coloured beer with a white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops, fruit, caramel and bitterness.

Clear dark golden color with off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a hint of caramel. Taste follows, slightly sweet and malty at first, more dry and bitter on the finish with lingering hop flavor. Medium body and carbonation. Overall its a decent beer, resembles a sweeter APA.
Poured from can orange hue with white head tastes like cream and slight hints of sweet wheat aroma is lightly hop and vanilla.

Can. Dynamic fresh smell of malt, hop, wheat, vanilla and spices. Light creamy ale with some hop bitterness and sugar but it isnt sweet like candied sugar. Nice stuff. I like their C.R.E.A.M. better.
Light orange hue. Tastes like cream and slight hints of wheat and even root beer. Initial smell is lightly hoppy and vanilla. Aftertaste is wheaty and bitter. Nice treat!
Tasted at the monthly first Wednesday tasting at De Molen. Aroma is fruity, berries, creamy and with some floral hops. Flavor is slightly sweet, slightly bitter and a bit thin.
Buen cuerpo, espuma compacta. Aroma herbal. En boca un poco afrutada y resinosa, maltosa con final amargo. Lote 1831. BB 2017/02/08

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Rami Rami is drinking a Sweet Action by Sixpoint Brewery at JabeerwockyTakie dziwne, perfumowane, landrynkowo-owocowe, niezleOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).
355ml can from De Bierkoning. Pale orange with a medium white soapy head. Light to medium body with moderate carbonation. Quite sweet with subtle bitter tones. Caramel, malts and hops. Quite OK.

330 ml can. Pours a clear amber-orange with an off-white head. Aroma of lightly roasted malt (caramel) along with light herbal-flowery hop notes. Medium nearly flat body with a short light to medium sweetness followed by a light to medium bitterness. Apart from the bitter notes a rather quick finish. The flavor reminds of strawberries, peach and dried apples but is quickly overshadowed by the bitterness with some.

Strange beast we have here. Huge malt sweetness, deep and caramel-filled, yet immediately overturned by a pungent hoppy middle and back. Citric and piney on the fade, with a lingering undercurrent of sticky malt heaviness. Kind of like an attempt to make a light beer approximation of an old ale or a barleywine. Im digging this brew, but I feel like I need another one to be sure where I stand.
gedeeld met lion tijdens de verhuizing. goudgeel met een witte kraag. Heerlijk fris met mango en ananas sour cream in de afdronk.
A bit like a barleywine without the heavy alcohol. Malty, hoppy, sweet, slightly sticky sweet. Medium body, nice carbo.
(Tap) clear, bright orange colour with a small white head; aroma of jam, bit of citrus; creamy palate; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish

Draft at Cottonwood - A beautiful beer, slightly hazed orange-amber - massive, frothy white head. Beautiful lacing, very consistent and sticky. Aroma is pretty subdued, bready, sweet. Nice creamy mouthfeel indeed, peach syrup. hops. Not bad at all, nothing outstanding other than the appearance though.

12 oz single from Lifesource in Salem Oregon.
$1.79
Pours a nice deep golden colour with a lovely looking creamy off white head.
Curious aromas fruit, corn and hops Like creamy cherry soda..
Nice bitter sweet taste..balanced and finishes semi-bitter.
Good well carbonated mouth feel.
Nice beer but different from any Cream Ale i have ever tasted.
Poured from can...pours a cloudy gold with 2 finger white head..nose is minimal just not much to it....taste is sweet hoppy fruity caramel goodness...really solid brew.

Piwo ma bursztynowy kolor i jest całkowicie klarowne. Cechuje go wspaniała, biała, puszysta piana, która pozostawia piękny lacing na ściankach.
W aromacie pół na pół słodów i chmieli. 
Lekkie tosty i karmel od słodów, a po drugiej stronie barykady owoce cytrusowe i tropikalne.
W smaku słodkawe, karmelowe, biszkoptowe z porządny kopnikiem cytrusowym w tle.
Średnia goryczka z wytrawnym, cytrusowym finiszem.
Pełne ciało i łatwa pijalność.
Fajne piwko.
From labirratorium. In Teku glass. After dinner, with pok cheese. One month before bb date. Promises but feels a bit old, specially in mouth. Nice bitter feeling. To repeat fresher.

355ml can - thanks Martjoobolut!
Yuck, extremely sweet caramelly aroma, and sticky sweet fruity hops at first, but they fade soon. Soapy in the mouth, harsh metallic aspects. Sweet malts, a bit stale, but still well in BB. Finish bitter. Yucky bitter brew, no balance,and less than zero drinkability. Thank goodness this was shared...

Can, bb 08.11.2016 (from beernavigator). Pours amber. Aroma is hoppy, toasty, malty, greasy. Flavor is sweet and bitter, hoppy, malty, toasty, caramel, citrus, vanilla. Finish is some dry bitterness. Drinkability is ok. Overall: ok

355ml Red Bull can (thanks Mart). Clear amber color. Small size, white head, stays. Sweet, caramel, hops, citrus and fruity in aroma. Typical American aroma. Caramel, hard candy, fruity, sweet in taste. Soft hoppy bitterness. Medium carbonation. Clean palate. Spicy tingly hops on tongue. Drinkable brew.

Drank from a 12 oz can at Battery Gardens Restaurant / The Beer Garden in Manhattan New York on September 22, 2016. Honey amber, small head. Sweet malty peach aroma, a bit hoppy, The taste is much hoppier, notes of citrus and pine, dry bitterness. A fairly decent ale, fun to drink!

Can 35,5cl
@ LaBIRRAtorium, Madrid, Spain.
A: Amber.
T: Malt, sweet, slightly hoppy.

From can, the pour is clear and dirty blond with a white head that lingures. The aroma is light hops and a little citrus. The taste is malty a little sweet and nice bright hop presence that is complimentary. The mouthfeel is thin and the finish is crisp.

Can at a tasting. Lots of hoppiness, but mostly in aroma and flavour, not so much bitterness. Flavour dominated by resiny zesty orange hops, though rather sweet, with decent clean crystal caramelly biscuity maltiness. Tasty, interesting mix with malty sweetness and hoppy aromatics.
Can. Golden color with medium white head. Malty aroma with distinct citrus hops. Taste, malt, light caramel, light citrus hops. Medium long car smelly, light hoppy finish. Good.
UPDATED: SEP 28, 2016 Can at tasting.Copper colour. Aroma sweet a little bit of orange zest. Taste is sweet with bitter aftertaste.

Peachy amber.. Aroma is mellow hops, mild toast caramel, mineral. Same in taste, clean, crisp finish. Good drinking beer for its abv. Strong carb. Medium sweet, not that bitter. Maybe some orange fruit character. Kind of between a pale ale and a light amber.

Pours a deep amber with a medium white head which lingers a bit......aroma is sweetness, touch of pine, slight orange......taste is citrus, sweetness, nice backbone, crisp.....a fair representation of an American Pale. Thankfully no biscuitty taste, so well done.
Really interesting and enjoyable beer. Malts cut with a lovely sweetness to the pallet. Really enjoyable

On tap at Luckys Supermarket in East Orlando. They had it labeled as Pale Ale, but after looking for it, then remembering was on the mild side, this must be it...as one of their more mass produced beers, and already had the Resin IPA and definitely was not that. A little hoppier than most cream ales. Maybe some sort of hybrid? Sampled a quick pint while grocery shopping, so may have to try again now that I know what Im drinking.

Medium sized, tight beaded tan colored head with good retention and a fair lace. Copper in color. Grainy nose, hint of lemon. Body is medium with a soft carbo, lil oily with a tanginess. Fairly dry, some caramel malts, hop spices and grain. Dry finish, tame bite. Decent Cream Ale. Can donated by coldbrewky.

0,355l can at home. At the bottom it says something about 12/2015, I hope it means canned on. amber clear color, medium big off-white head. smells of resin, some exotic fruits, passion fruit, some lychee, rather nice smell. light to medium body, soft carbonation, rather watery mouthfeel. tastes of resin, light caramel, some exotic fruits, bit breadish. finishes very light with hints of bitterness and some piney notes. interesting one, taste is very light (maybe also related to freshness(?), but overall very easy to drink. I kinda like it.

Big citrus fruit and floral scents quite sweet smelling. Pours dark brown with a good tight white head. Some lacing. Nice big tastes of citrus and melon balanced exceptionally well with a hoppy finish that prevents the sweet from dominating. Medium carbonation. Exceptional summer quaff.

Probada de grifo en Boilermaker, East Village, New York. Septiembre 2016. No tan cremosa cream ale, pero muy disfrutable. 7/10

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a slightly hazy golden color aroma is a Lil malty with some orange tastes a little piney other great balance of bitterness and sweetness very solid

Sampled at SBWF 2015.
Short white head. Clear light amber color. Medium hop aroma. Mild hop taste and a fresh sparkle.

Clear Amber thin foamy Lacy beige head; aroma is malt with touch of hop spice; flava is balance of hop spice and malt def notes of caramel; feels medium with foamy fizz; finishes dry mild tang and bitter balance

Taster pour at Craft Beer Race New Haven. Appearance is light brown, like a root beer candy, tiny head and lacing, no sparkle. Aroma is malty. Taste is mildly like wort--somewhat unfinished--but mix of malt and herbal hops. Palate is medium bodied with average-to-thick texture, soft carbonation and finish like taste. Overall, pretty mild and simple. Some conflicting tastes that dont work so well and seems a bit unfinished.

On tap at Darbys, pours a hazy orange amber with a small off-white head. Aroma brings out quite a lot of resinous hops and light caramel malt - sure smells potent for a cream ale. Flavour is more malty, with caramel bready malt, some strange cardboardy notes, and fairly aggressive resins. A cream ale on steroids. Not the most pleasant but its certainly more interesting than most in this boring style.
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2016 On tap at Darbys with Mark. Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is creamy, some fruity notes, slightly dirty. Similar taste. Not bad.
Ámbar limpio y espuma marfil. Aromas suaves de malta, ligero caramelo, cítrico. Cuerpo ligero, con inicio maltoso suave que da paso a un sabor cítrico breve y un final seco.

Copper color with a thin head. Aroma like orange marmalade. Moderate orange and caramel flavor. Fairly solid bitterness. Touch of barley. A bit of vegetal hop on the finish. Dry. Full body. Didnt expect much going in, but this is really nice!

355ml can. Barely clear amber colour with average, frothy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, off-white head. Fruity hoppy aroma has a touch of red currant, a middle layer of artificial cherry, some caramel, a minimally leafy-herbal touch. Taste is fairly bitter hoppy, slightly fruity, minimally artificial and sugary notes of red fruit, red currant, cherry, minimally sweet caramel malty basis. Due to the low number of ratings in this style, Im still in search of Cream Ale characteristics. This comes along as a cleaned and sweetened British Bitter.
Pours an amber body with a medium head. Nice hoppy aroma. Taste is a bit too bitter for a saison and the hops are too dominant.
Pours clear amber with a white head. Aroma of toast, pine and grass. Taste follows nose.
Pours a clear amber color with medium white head. Citrusy aroma, bready, biscuity, malty and caramely. Taste has citrus, bread, sweet malts, grain and pine, with a medium bitter finish to it.
Amber red. Quite hoppy for the style. Flavors of floral and pine hops. Lightness and drinkability of a lager. Pretty decent, even if it crosses style boundaries almost into IPL territory.

If I had to place this style, Id lean more toward altbier than cream ale. Nose reveals the drop hopping, somewhat floral, hint of citrus. Some toffeed malts in there too. Flavor is more malt, sweetish and caramelly, but with a nice floral bitterness right there. Bitter wack rises at the semi-dry finish, very reminiscent of altbier. Lingering floral hops in the aftertaste. Dark amber, almost tea colored, modest head.
Drank from a twelve ounce can. Was intrigued to try a cream ale, but found this guy was hoppy. Makes sense it has wet hops, But I dont categorize this as a cream ale...

Sample from can at Beertemple during Carnivale Brettanomyces 2016
clear golden white head. Aroma of malts, biscuit, caramel, sugar. Taste is sweet, grain, malty caramel, some hops, medium bitter, medium body,

THANKS for sharing RB people! Sampled draft @ Beer Temple during Carnivale Brettanomyces 2016! Clear orange, little tanned white head. Nose is sweet candy, overly oily, sweet, incense, weird, overly sweet, sugar, perfume & honey. Taste is weird watery oily butterscotch, butterscotch hop, weak sugar, oily sweet butterscotch, faint butter. Strange overly sweet butterscotch & incense beer. Didnt really get into it.

On tap at Carnivale Brettanomyces 16. At Beer Temple. Clear golden amber colour, white head. Aroma of pine, light nutty, caramel. Flavour is grainy, pine, nuts, caramel, hoppy bitter finish, grain. Light bodied. Meh..

Sampled from tap at Beertemple during Carnivale Brettanomyces 2016. Clear, golden amber with an off-white head. Sweetish, malty aroma of caramel, honey and some brown sugar. Sweetish, slightly bitter and malty taste of caramel, honey and some nuts, followed by a short, slightly bitter finish. Medium body, slightly creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Okay.

Tap @ Beer Temple (at Carnivale Brettanomyces 2016), with Bierkoning, Travlr, Zlotta, Kermis, Maakun, TheJvd, ShivanDragon and more. Clear golden to copper color. Off white head with some lacing. Aromas: grainish, fruity, along with some hop, resin retronasal. Flavor is moderate sweet, fruity. Body is rather thin. Finishes with a light bitterness. Not bad (for a cream ale).

Tap at BeerTemple. Clear golden with nice bubbly off white head. Light malts, quite some nice fruits with peach, apricot, lime. Light sweet and bitter. Under medium bodied with slick light feel. Quite nice.

Draft at Beer Temple. Clear amber with an off white head. Aroma of light fruits, tropical notes, peach, light citrus. Flavour is ligt to moderate sweet and light moderate bitter. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Can at home. Aroma is sweetish toasted biscuity malt, resinous hops, touch of fruits. Flavour is light to moderate sweet and moderate to medium bitter. Body is medium. Hardly a smasher like the Sixpoint Crisp or Bengali, but pretty smooth and agreeable.
Draft at beertemple. Clear pour. Aroma of creamy malt. Smooth taste of cream, some bitters hops and malt. Quite nice for a cream ale.

12 ounce can into pint glass, best before 3/18/2016. Pours slightly hazy/cloudy orange/amber color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and rocky off white head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice dense soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of grapefruit, lemon zest, orange peel, light pine, honey, toasted biscuit, light caramel/nuttiness, and floral/grassy earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus/floral hops and bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of grapefruit, lemon zest, orange peel, light pine, honey, toasted biscuit, light caramel/nuttiness, and floral/grassy earthiness. Light pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, lemon/orange zest, honey, toasted biscuit, and floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/floral hops and bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth and moderately creamy/bready/grainy mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 5.2%. Overall this is a great pale/cream ale hybrid style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/floral hops and bready malt flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink. A very enjoyable offering.
Amber pour, grainy aroma. Cereal, light fruit and caramel. Someone said lemongrass...I can see it. Nice full mouthfeel, coating on the tongue. Still zippy fruitiness. I liked it.

Smells of sweet malts oatmeal lemongrass and a touch Orange rind at the end. See through amber color. Taste starts off with slightly sweet malts followed by lemongrass a bit of Orange with a slightly bitter dry finish. Light body with sweet crisp carbonation. Not to many flavors in this brew but the ones that stand out I really enjoy this is a great summer beer. Nice work!
Pours an amber from a can. Tropical fruit and slight citrus notes in the nose, somewhat dank resinous flavor is added to the mix, very thin, not much malt backbone. Meh.

(Sixpoint Sweet Action) Can 355 ml at home, served into a shaker, ABV 5.2%. Second cream ale.
Deep orange colour on the body, mostly clear, with a tall but thin off-white head on top, with good retention.
Aroma has citrus, grassy hops, tangerine.
Taste has caramel malts, hops giving flavours of citrus, light orange peel, tangerine, nicely bitter on the finish.
Medium body, good amount of carbonation.
Very good.

12 oz can. Hazy, burnt orange colored beer with a frothy, white head. Aromas of grassy hops. Tastes of grassy/floral hops, some toffee, and toasted malt. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. Bittersweet in the finish with some grapefruit/citrus notes. Hoppier than expected, more like an IPA than a cream ale in my opinion.

Looking to try a good cream ale, and this isnt it. Pours a nice clear copper wit h thin white top. Aroma hits with hops foremost when I was hoping for malt. Way too much hops in the flavor and aftertaste obscures what may be decent malt characteristics. Ultimately this is just a strange take on pale ale.
Can. Pours amber with off white head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is thin, sweet malty with a little sweet hoppy finish. Easy drinker but forgettable.
Can - pours dark orange with a small lacy head. Aroma is quite hippy withstand decent amount of caramel. Taste is nicely balanced hop and malt come through right across the palate. Creamy mouthfeel.

12 oz signature Sixpoint can. Lighter clear golden pour with a thin fizz head. Surprised to see the cream ale tag here. Drinks more like a sweeter side pale. Hop sturdy and a refreshing, cool finish. Nice beer.

Surprisingly dark, burnished orange hue; clear with a skimming of off-white. Creamed corn and rancid butter in the aroma after an early rush of bright, melony hop and honey. Slick, sweet, a touch hot, wooden bitterness, nail polish. The flavor is burly and disoriented, with bitter orange peel and pine clumsily suffocating whatever stylistic integrity might be present. It is medicinal and cloyingly sweet, with a vanilla hard candy flavor that can fall in the diacetyl spectrum. There is no crisp edge to the heavy-leaning body; it seems unlikely this could ever be blindly recognized as a cream ale.
Tap at McCoys. Pint glass. Light copper with small head and poor lacing. Subtle hop aroma. Sweet and light fruit . Oily resin and pleasant finish.
Its pretty good all the way around, but because of its pronounced hop characteristics, gets points off for not being true to style. Still really good drinking beer. Would have again.

Can from Beers of the World, Henrietta. Pleasant light fruity c-hop aroma. Tastes like a great IPA... That?s been watered down. Bitter sweet c-hops, and pine. Good, but, as I mentioned, a little watery.
Great balance of the described sweet and bitter. Aroma is citrus and floral, preps your palate for an ipa like punch. Flavor is surprisingly sweet and creamy. Very smooth and sessionable.

Nice clear copper pour with a rocky head. Chunky lacing. Nose is caramel malt and herbal hops. Kinda sweet, some toffee, faint metal. Palate is pretty light. More floral and herbal hop flavor, but with muted bitterness. Coffee notes. Finishes with lingering herbal hop and caramel. Kinda weird, and not really what one would expect from a cream ale. Ok.

Yellowish color, small off white head. Aroma citrusy hops and some malt. Medium body, some carbonation. Flavor is mostly similar to a pale ale with nice balance of hops and malt, more towards the sweet side, very drinkable.

Bronze appearance with a large, off white head and very good lacing. Muted aroma of herbal hops and a faint whiff of tropical fruit. Flavor is a bit more citrusy and pairs with whole grain bread. There is a distracting metallic note in the aftertaste. Medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel and a lingering finish. Mixed reaction to this one, especially as how true it is to the cream ale style.

Beautiful dark brown appearance, lively CO2...and tons and tons of hops. for North American craft beer-heads its normal and they can rate accordingly, but in Europe this is overkill esp for the style, and makes it downright unenjoyable

Copper colored with decent head and smells of hops. Little more bitter than sweet but still a very good brew that is very enjoyable. About a dollar or two more per six pack than other comparable brews so not planning on making this an every day one.

1.5dl on tap at Craft & Draft, Amsterdam. Body is clear golden orange, head is big, off-white, creamy, average lasting, excellent lacing. Nose is floral, flavor is fruity, floral, citric, mandarin, grass, hemp. Medium sweet, light bitter, light fruity sour. Finish is long lasting hoppy medium bitter. Light body, thin texture, nearly flat carbonation. Easy, refreshing, simple and tasty APAish beer.

355ml can into pint. Smells of hops and stonefruit. Bronze beer, fluffy head, many fine bubbles. Quite sharp mouthfeel. Finish is oranges, resin and late Juicy-Fruit. Its a great beer but is it a Cream Ale? Doesnt have a creamy texture and too MUCH flavour for my understanding of the style.

Draft @ Uiltje bar, Haarlem. Clear amber with a small white head. Aroma of sweet malts, honey, hops, bread. Taste is bitter sweet, sweet malts, bitter hops, light fruity. Light bitter sweet hoppy aftertaste. Bit thin, but not bad.

not really screaming cream ale. nice balance of malt and hops, but other than that...
Nice sessionable brew. Not too complicated.

Aroma is a little malty and a little hoppy. Some citrus, ripe oranges and white bread. Taste is clean and on the lower spectrum. Subtle hops and lemon zest in a medium malty soup. Theres a hint of sweet melon before it turns to a mid bitter finish.
Dandelion nose. Clear amber, medium head. Lemongrass and rosehip. Light body, easy carbonation. Hoppy and easy drinking, session IPAish.
Burk från whole foods nyc. Ljust gul med vitt skum. Fruktig doft med en del karamell. Lätt, ganska tråkig smak.

Draught, small bubbly head, clear deepish orange color, aroma of grapefruit and pine, flavor of grapefruit, lemon and some soapy flowery, medium grapefruit bitterness..Good and enjoyable, resembles an IPA.

Tap @Drexclers. Aroma is orange, light malts and caramel. Deep amber, clear, small white head. Light/medium sweetness, light bitter, taste is round malts, hints of orange, sweet citrus fruits. Medium body, soft, small bitterness in a long aftertaste. Very smooth beer, nice!
On tap. Pours hazy amber with thin white head. Citric aroma, grapefruit and orange. Taste is light bitter and malty. Easy drinking, light body.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2015 12 oz. can from Boombox mixpack into a tulip
Canned on 7/23/2015
A: Dark amber, brand new motor oil hue with an inch of fine foam and visible bubbles lazily rising.
S: Toasty brown bread scent with a spicy hop backing. Cinnamon? Orange zest?
T: Malty but bitter at once. Fairly crisp flavor. Roast maltiness mainly. More like a light amber ale to me.
M: Light bodied and almost watery. Crisp with average carbonation. Medium short sour finish.
O: Fairly tasty but simple and overall pretty average. Glad I had the chance to try this but wont likely be a repeat purchase.
Medium amber, off white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, loads of pine. Light to medium body, flavour is lightly sweet, moderately bitter.

On tap at rapture. Deep golden. Smells of honey potential strawberry or some other fruit. Taste is a slick honey with some fruity undertones. A bit of a gassy Lagery finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: Light amber, clear. Some off-white head.
Aroma: Fruit, floral. Honey?
Taste: Hops, light fruit, then a bit watery, followed by a bit of sweetness. Dry. Hmm.
Bought: Total Wine (Sterling), 355 ml can, $2.29
Info: 16/9-2015, BB: 20/5-2016
12 ounce can. Pours a dark copper color with a small white head. A sweet malty toast nose. Sweet sugary malts, bready, light fruity hops. Ok. Caramel.
Smells very sweet and malty with medium hops, taste is much hoppier than expected, the malt sweetness is gone, somehow pretty much became an IPA...very weird... Too hoppy

On tap at Tapastre: amber orange with small, off-white head that disappears quickly but leaves attractive lacing.
The nose is mild lemon, orange, grass, pine. Flavor begins as sprightly citrus with a hint of caramel, but underlying pine soon comes to the fore. Thats particularly true as it aerates. After 15 minutes, youre drinking Pinesol and food does not help. 
Quaff it quickly or leave it.

Can. Pours amber orange with a thin beige head. Aroma of citrus, grass and caramel. Flavor of citrus hops, orange, caramel, pine and some light fruit.

Can at The Village Inn (Wetherspoons), Rayners Lane. An orange/amber coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Hoppy, floral, caramel aroma. Tastes similar, hoppy, floral, caramel. Quite drinkable.

The flavor is a mirror image of the aroma, I find their "Sweet Action"; for me, its clover honey in light malts, a slight pine resin across my tongue, very dry after the swallow. In any case, the description on this stealthy CTA-ready can makes the beer sound like its going to be some heavily malt centric Amber or something but its actually more along the lines of an American Pale Ale. It is orange in color with a small white head that leaves behind little patches of lacing. The nose is very much focused on American hops, smells like pine w/ a slight savory character. Flavor is a touch sweet and the main thing I am noticing is a flavorful tea leaf astringent note and a touch lemon and mandarin orange from the hops. It is medium bodied but still feels pretty light on the palate thanks to moderate carbonation. It finishes w/ a resinous bitterness and some lingering sugary malt character. This definitely isnt a bad beer for drinking on the bus or train... I mean anywhere but the bus or train.

(On tap) Clear amber with some white head. Little aroma. Light body with plenty of fine bright carbonation. Very unusual taste. Part beer, part cream soda. However it isn't particularly sweet. Out the can it is darker than expected, slightly hazy and a burnished, deep orange in colour. Soppy, compact white crown atop produces a fine lace. Pours hazy orange, the color of blush on a peach. Tall head of soft, eggshell colored foam that dwindled to a layer on top and some creamy lace. Nose is fruity and juicy with peach and orange citrus. Theres a playful bite on the nose from the simcoe hops and a little pepper. Underneath is good bready malt thats honey sweet. Taste is light and fruity with floral hops, peach, apricot and orange peel. The cracker and bread are sturdy but light as a feather and carry all that fruit over the palate with ease. Finishes with another bite from the simcoe on the back palate and leaves dry with a sticky, sweet aftertaste and a touch of bitter. Body is creamy and although well carbonated, it was downright silky. 

This beer wasnt short on hops at all and the hop character was intense but without oil or too much bitter. The simcoe never got catty and the bread, while sweet, never outclassed the fruit. Easy to see why Sixpoint was #1 at the NYS TAP festival. So far each offering is unique and expertly done. This was a graceful interpretation of a cream ale that drank easily and with a little panache.

3.0 A: Moderately hazed dark orange brown color. Two and a half fingers of beige, frothy/foamy head. Retention is average and moderate amounts of randomly dispersed clumps of lacing are left behind.

3.0 T: Solid blending of the yeast, malt, and hops, but the end result doesnt impress or discourage. Grainy malts with a moderate neutral malt sweetness. Mild bitterness with earth, herb, and flower hop flavor. Mild yeasty breadiness. Not bad, but run of the mill. 

3.5 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Light, pleasant creaminess.

3.0 D: Not a bad brew, but theres enough similar, yet tastier ones out there to forget about this.

Can shared @ The Rover. Pours tiny hazy copper with a frothy off-white head that clings to the glass while slowly dissipating leaving some thick lacing. Smell is sweet and slightly malty with toffee, honeydew melon, plums, sweet very ripe oranges, vanilla fudge and very subtle hints of cocoa powder. Taste is sweet, slightly fruity and tiny metallic with toffee, cereal, honeydew melon, orange juice, lemon zest, dried grass and canned peaches. Mouthfeel is creamy, slightly watery and light bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and tiny bitter with grass, prunes, lemon zest and lemon flavored hard candy.

(Can) Pours copper  with a sand colored head. The aroma holds soft pine and fruits from the hops alongside toast and a touch of wheat. Creamy and soft on the nose. Hints of fudge. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter and tiny acidic with notes of toast, wheat, bread, citrus and hints of fruits. The mouthfeel is watery, light tart and soft with light to medium carbonation. Citric and wheaty finish. Light bodied.

Pours darker than most cream ales, with a thin layer of white head that disappears fairly quick.  Lacing is average.  Slight hoppy presence in the aroma...maybe some citrus.  Nice malt and slight wheat presence in the taste.  Pretty good cream ale.

Can [473ml]. Pours a cloudy, bubbly orange-amber with an average size diminishing frothy off-white head. Semi-mild aroma of resiny hops, light sweetness, sweet pale malt, some fruit and spices. Flavour of hops and fruit along with pale malt and spices. Decent bitter finish. More like a Pale Ale then a Cream Ale, which is a good thing. Medium bodied. Nothing great but its pretty good, I liked it.

-- Rated via Beer Buddy.

Can from a local deli.  the guys there went out their way to help me.  and even split up a few of these 4 packs for me.  I was impressed with the service.  that place belongs on ratebeer for their service alone.  and a not too shabby selection.  anyway.  back to this berrr.  Super orange hazy with a medium sized white sudsy head.  Nose is sweet, but not overly sugary, some light citrus and resinous hops,  a little bit vegetal,  dust and dirt lingering.   Flavor is pretty good. Mildly sweet, mildly bitter.  Nothing great (but still a very good cream ale for all i know, just not my style), but easy drinking and approachable cream ale.

Can.  Poured a medium sized off-whte head that was mostly lasting, fair amount of lacing, hazy body, fast rising carbonation, and a golden hue.  The Aroma was malty, semi-sweet and pine.  Ditto for the Flavor.  The Mouthfeel was mildly tingly and this is a medium bodied Cream Ale beer.  Overall, this beer had very subtle aromas and flavors which took away from the overall experience of drinking/rating.

16oz. can - Pours lightly hazy amber with a big foamy off-white head. Light herbal hopping on the nose, big barley graininess, and a light honey sweetness. Really big fluffy carbonation thats extremely smooth in the mouth. Grainy taste as well, with a bit sharper hop profile, a bit of toffee, and a drying mineral finish. The hops just have a bit of boozy sharpness to them that are a bit off-putting. Id like to see them a bit smoother. Still, its easy-to-drink and flavorful, without being too heavy. Light years different than Spotted Cow even as theyre both listed as cream ales, but Id take this any day of the week.

Tasted from can at Standard market, Westmont. A darker gold color than the Crisp pils. Smell is much lighter, almost hard to find. But the taste more than makes up for it. Kind of citrusy, like a pale ale at first. Then a slight spicy note of wheat malts.
UPDATED: OCT 5, 2015 From Genes. Strange beer. Creamy and sweet. Hops at the very end hiding under other flavors, seems out of place. Flat palate. Not bad but maybe not my thing. Serving: Can

16 oz. can.  What? A cream ale? That isnt spotted cow?  AWESOME.  Pours a hazy amber pour with a bright, white, thick head.  Aroma of herbal hops, amber and caramel malt.  Mild sweetness in the nose as well.  Flavor is balanced between mild sweet and mild bitter notes.  Nice, creamy sweetness towards the back of the throat.  Medium bodied.  Finishes on a bitter note.  This was a very nice surprise.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2013 Draft. Slightly dark cloudy amber. Big head that disappeared quickly. Would not consider this a cream ale. More a marriage of light toasty malted ale and a standard IPA. Not much aroma but some lively flavor. Slight hop bite but fairly smooth start to finish. Good session brew.

Actually somewhat dark for a cream ale. Looks like a dark IPA, almost an amber. Thin head. Aroma is sweet and yeasty. A hint of orange. Flavor is much the same. That pervasive doughy, yeasty flavor that I dont care for in NA beers. Defined spike of orangey hops in the back. Low on the bitterness, letting the sweetness show through. A little hint of woody resin in the middle. Pretty full of flavor for the style. Carbonation is a little heavy. Full bodied and slick on the tongue. Just a weird beer. Blindly, Id have to guess this was an APA, but with something off about it. It doesnt fit the typical Cream Ale mold, but then again Ive never really figured out the point of a Cream Ale anyway. Not bad, but Id rather see something else as a regular offering from Sixpoint.

Can. Lager Glass. Pours a murky caramel brown color. Fluffy off-white head. Hops are dominant in the aroma, and there is grass, a touch or orange peel/lemon, with some pine. Palate is bitter with hop up front, then mellows into malts and finishes sweet. Flavor varies from corn/grain, then piny hops, then caramel malts. At times, it wants to be watery, then pilsner-like, but then it finishes more like a malty lager, and texture like a hefe would. But its neither in the end. But, I put it above other beers as it looks good and the taste is interesting enough.

A: Pours a light golden color with a two-finger soapy white head with good retention and lacing. The body itself looks a bit yeasty.

S: The smell features some almost weizen-esque esters (banana, cloves, allspice), along side a noble aspect.

T/M: Honestly, the flavor is a bit lacking. Whats there isnt bad...there just isnt much there in the first place. Theres a very subtle sweetness on the open, while the finish is purely bready, with the murky, earthy notes hindering its refreshment. Apparently, I know next to jack shit about cream ales, other than the fact that theyre basically pale lagers with more ester-y goodness (whatever the blue hell that means), and that this doesnt seem to be a traditional cream ale. Still, Id gladly trade some of the fruity notes on the open for a crisper finish. Its a little too rough and chalky on the tongue, but its well carbonated.

O: This is a beer that doesnt know what it wants to be. Is it a weak pale ale or a muddy pilsener? Maybe I should chalk it up to me not getting this style of beer. Probably wont revisit this in the future.

Exactement lidée que je me faisais dune cream ale. Sucré à la façon dun crème soda avec une texture assez ronde. Légère amertume pour balancer le givrage sucré. Belle représentation dun style qui mexcite rarement.

On tap. Slightly hazy orange color. Off-white head. Interesting, unique sweet taste... Its like kettle corn, I think. Splotchy lace. Lighter, soft carbonation> Dry texture. Kind of salty - sweet taste. Interesting brew.

Pours a cloudy amber, with a nice sized head.  Thick looking beer.  Im getting floral hops in the nose... Is that what a cream ale should smell like?  This smells more like an IPA to me.  Anyway, on to the taste.  Ok, this is a straight up IPA.  Hoppy and bitter, with a strong malt backbone.  Why do they claim only 34 IBUs?  Its clearly more than that.  Anyway, its a damn good beer, and world class if this is in fact a "cream ale".  Fuck it, I like it.

(16oz can) Hazy orange body with a medium, creamy white head. Mildly sweet malt aroma; lemon and iced tea. Light to medium body, some carbonation. Flavor of lemon, grass, mildly sweet, tea, some yeast. Mild bitter finish.

Pretty refreshing; I could drink a few of these while sitting outside on a nice day. And my first cream ale.

Pours a rich copper color with a minimal head... nice balance of sweet and bitter coming through... a little burnt sugar mixed with a wild bret on the front end and a little saaz style bitterness on the finish.

another in the sixpoint lineup. enjoyed a can in my pils glass. Deep orangey yellow like the edges of the can label. Hazey with a half finger head. Aroma is some light citrus , maybe some grape candy flavor and paper. Taste is light and wild, bitter with fresh matiness coming in the finish. Very refreshing, may buy more for a cookout.

Location/Date:Can on March 28th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a cloudy dark orange. 
Aroma: Citrusy, light.
Taste:Medium light bitterness, nice amount of sweetness from the malt. Not overbearing, balanced.
Palate:Medium light, really smooth and creamy. Quick finish,
Summary: My first cream ale rating!  This beer is really interesting - there is a nice amount of flavor of bitterness and sweet, but it is not overbearing. Im really impressed by the palate of how smooth it is and quick to finish. This is a really nice beer especially considering the alcohol percentage of 5.2%, could be "sessionable".
Tall boy.  Slightly cloudy copper pour with a thin off white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, yeast and bitter earthy hops.  Medium bodied creamy taste with a slight citrusy hoppy finish.

I am impressed.  I love it when a canned beer comes through.  Darker pour than expected.  What is good here is how fresh it seems.  Very goot blend of malt and hops to give it a perfect blend of bitter/sweet!  Now to find it consistantly!

Birthday beer #1, Sixpoint just arrived in Indianapolis yesterday.

This beer pours a light to medium bodied orangish dull copper in color with a creamy white, one finger head. Its much darker than I anticipated. The aromas are different than I expected. I get some slightly sweet amber malts, light citrus, light happiness, and it has a certain creaminess to it, indicative of a can.The flavors are light and smooth. I get a lot of smooth malts with citrus accents and a ever so slight hop bitterness. It is incredibly smooth and creamy, obviously made for a can. Its solid, and much different than other cream ales Ive had. It has more body and isnt as session able yet has more flavor and more to offer.

Sure doesnt smell like a cream ale, like sticking my nose in a hop bin,defintely more American Pale Aleish,,a successful dry hopping procedure, that pretty much dominates the nose. Taste is however totaly unlike the aroma,here you get a straight balance of grain malt and grain hop,then hop bitterness in finish, That balanced blend is then washed from the palate almost immediately after the swallow,very mysterious how that happens. I take it this is supposed to be a surprising mix of malt sweetness(hence that Cream ale designation) and hop bitterness, but that quick ghostly appearance and disappearance of the malt ,makes a style assignment impossible. Very drinkable,session type,would go great with a spicey sweet salsa

Pint-sized can.  Poured slightly hazy medium orange with a creamy beige head.  The aroma picked up sweet pale malts and fruity notes, with white spices and a touch of orange zest accenting.. really nice.  The flavor opened with tangy carbonation and the aforementioned spices, pale and fruity notes supported the core.. tangy fruit skins and spices on the edges, with more fruity character through the finish.. a tad sharper than expected, but I cant say it didnt work.  Light-medium bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. it wanted to be smooth, but sharpness and some residual bitterness got in the way.. overall a solid brew that Id drink again.

Can: Poured a medium bright amber color ale with a large white foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of semi-sweet caramel malt with light citrus hoppy notes. Taste is also a good mix between some caramelized malt with a light hoppy finish with subtle notes of citrus. Body is about average with good carbonation. Nice session style beer with limited complexity.
Pours an amber color with off-white head.  Aroma is mostly malty with caramel malts. Slight hint of citrus hops as well.  Creamy mouthful with citrus hops and caramel malts.  Decent bitter finish.

Poured from a can into a pint glass. Appearance is all nuances, nothing pronounced. I get a some hop bitterness, some creamy malt sweetness, some estery wheat influence. I like how all this melds together to make a nicely done, sessionable beer. Taste is mildly flavorful, while remaining quaffable. A big drink is not out of the question. Creamy mouthfeel and somewhere between light and medium bodied. Finish is abrupt, but thats what it ought to be.

I poured a 16oz can into a lager glass.

Appearance: Dark orange color with a hazy body, although carbonation bubbles of different sizes and speeds are easily visible. Forms a good sized eggshell colored, frothy head which retains and laces very well.

Smell: Light confectionary notes of toffee and caramel, plus some more rustic aroma of black tea, honey roasted peanuts and floral hops.

Taste: The palate to Sixpoint Sweet Action is something of a contradiction. Its quite complex (surprisingly so, in fact), but its not all that robust or delectably delicious. It begins quite mild with a light nutty sweetness plus some candy flavor. It seems to turn on a dime into something quite stronger, though. Toffee, caramel, honey, and the faintest hint of citrusy hop bitterness all come through in the second half. It finishes much like it begins on a mild, subtle note with hint of herbal tea. 

Whats interesting is that throughout the entire palate theres a barely detectable lager-like component at the core. Its reminiscent of a Vienna or Munich-style lager or even an Oktoberfest. Slightly grassy, slightly lemony, a tad astringent, but aside from using the term "grainy" (which I hate), its best described as an all-malt lager character. The aftertaste is a mild chalky bitterness and texture, but the beer itself is quite refreshing while its in the mouth. Plenty of flavor to enjoy, but kept at a "lower volume" so as not to overwhelm.

Drinkability: While Sweet Action may have some lager character to the palate, its delivery is all ale for sure. The mouthfeel is a soft, medium-to-light body with an almost creamy texture. Despite all the carbonation you can see in the glass, it doesnt interfere with the drinking process as it goes down very smoothly. At only 5.2% ABV, Sixpoint definitely deserves kudos for being able to get so much flavor out of the brew. Technically too big to be a "session beer," but I could see most drinkers having no trouble with a 4-pack box of this over the course of a day or a weekend and still being able to function.

Can. Poured hazy amber color with a moderate frothy white head that lasted with good lacing. Moderate hop sweet aroma. Medium body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a smooth bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid refreshing brew for style.

Tap at Sunswick. Pours a hazy golden orange with standard white head. Aroma is a fine balance of mustiness and pine-like hops. Flavor has an overwhelming taste of overcooked mac n cheese. An odd elbow macaroni flavor lingers. A slight saltiness and dough flavor. Weird.

Pours hazy orange with a big off white head. Smells floral with sweet fruits. Taste floral, citrus, hay, and a little caramel. Smooth texture. Slightly bitter after taste. Overall, this is not bad, but nothing to go wild for.

16oz can poured into a pilsener glass.  Pours a hazy orange with a huge creamy white head that leaves a nice lacing pattern all the way down the glass.  The aroma is grassy, spicy, earthy hops, and some bread.  The taste is sour citrus, light malt, and medium bitterness.  The body is a bit too watery for my liking.  Its ok but nothing special.

The final surviving can from a nice haul courtesy of AndrewNations in the SS BIF. 16 oz. aluminum cylinder, I salute you ere I consume you.

Poured into a glass that came in the same box, this is big, fluffy, yellow leaning towards orange. Runaway carbonation is readily apparent. Smell is brimstone hops mixed with grain husks & several pinches of allspice. Hop presence is startling for the claimed 34 IBUs. Hmmm.

Sweet Action is only the third cream ale Ive ever had, & doesnt win me over to the style. Yawning disconnect between nose & taste, this is crawling with heavy, bready malts. Very grainy, soft herbal hops, tangerine. Theres an oddness lurking in the aftertaste that isnt welcome, & I cant quite pinpoint it. Musty, with a side of margarine. Not terrible, but certainly knocks the taste a bit & ruins the cleanliness of the initial flavors. I love big cans, but 12 oz. of this would have been plenty.

The slight off-taste really brings this one down. I love a good session ale (whatever the ABV), but if theyre not perfect, they can rapidly become suspect. This one is close, but the aftertaste really corrupts a good experience. Not bad, not good, decent enough.

Pours amber with a thin white/tan head.  Aroma is malty with light wheaty notes...mild toasty toffee.  Flavor is very bready and earthy...light and crisp tea-like hop notes...refreshing.  mouthfeel is light/medium with a bready/earthy finish that has mild sweet maltiness.
dark golden color, hazy with a nice head. a distinctive odor and distinctive medicinal  flavors. malts and hops for sure but cant get past this hint of pungent chemical solvents. may be out of date.

Can at the dutch, pours an amber haze, small head with minimal retention. Nose is lighty crackyness. Taste has sharp citrus bitterness mulded by undertones of sweet cereal and malt. Mouth is light and slick. Minimal carbonation. Tasty little cream ale.

Rated via BeerBuddy

Sample from can at the Strange Brew Tasting on 02/18/2012. Copper-colored with a medium off-white head that burns away steadily. Spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus, grain and a bit of hops. Light body with flavors of grassy hops, grainy malt and fruit. The finish is short with a sweet malt aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.
Can shared by a friend. Pours a hazy gold with a thick off-white head. Creamy sweet malt nose with grassy hops. Creamy and sweet malt flavor with grassy hops in the finish.

Can. Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with a massive super creamy head. Aroma is all sweet. Not a malty sweet but more of a candy sweet. Taste is very balanced with a small bitterness up front and a nice sweetness on the back. The middle is all sweet flavors. For what it is, great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sampled on tap pours a light brown with a khacki head.  Aromas of carmel toffee and some slight cereal.  Flavor is semi sweet with alot of malt pushing through.  Body is medium and finish is a bit lingering

Pours with a moderate pillowy head and lots of hop aroma. Before actually sampling this beer I would have thought that I poured a pilsner, it really has a great aroma. Pours a cloudy golden color, with a mild citrus flavor with a smooth almost creamy mouth feel and slight hop flavor.

"Purchased in a 4-pack for about $12 at Co-Op in Lebanon, NH. Poured into a Newcastle glass at 40 Degrees F

A - Poured a single finger head which dissipated quickly. The color is a very deep tan color but yet still very light. Its a very hazy beer which I attribute to the delicious dry hops.

S - Caramel, sugar, almonds and orange peel. Very small citrus notes and very sweet. Theres a deep mahogany wood character to this.

T - The caramel and orange peel are easy to pick up in the taste. Theres a more strong pine wood taste thats coming through now. Burnt brown sugar..maybe something more bitter like onions is hitting as well but its nice. Theres a hint of malt in here as well. It lives up to the name ""sweet action"" very well.

M - Light bodied and some really solid carbonation. The linger is pleasant and not overpowering.

O - A very decent canned ale. I bet this beer would have been better day-of fresh but its a great beer overall."

16oz can.

Pours a really cloudy orange with a huge fluffy beige head that leaves thick lacing on the sides and hangs around forever, being fed by a steady stream of bubbles from the bottom.

Aroma is full of toasted bread and and floral, slightly herbal, hop notes.  I get a little bit of citrus in the form of lemon zest and some creamy sweetness that I cant really place specifically.

Taste is crisp and bready up front with a light citrusy kick which transitions into some sweet caramel malts and creamy sweetness.  The finish is bitter with some herbal hops.

The mouthfeel is crisp and medium bodied for the style.

This is one of the better cream ales Ive had with more hops and a nice clean feel.  Very, very drinkable.

16oz can and on tap as well.  Pours out a darker orange hue, great carbonation.  Aromas are slightly bitter, but malty at the same time.  Palate is all over the place, some creamy textures up front, but it rips into an esb type bitterness towards the finish.  A little rough around the edges from the can, but a hell of a lot smoother from the tap.  Mixed feelings about this one, its maybe a bit too light, I expected something with a bit more weight.

Out of a can watching AFC final .. Very easy to drink , low carbonation and very balanced

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: AUG 11, 2012 Hazy copper color with an off white head. Balanced with a nice, somewhat hoppy finish. Smooth and very drinkable.

16 oz can thanks to ChairMissing.  Amber-orange in color.  Some caramel malt and slightly vegetal hops.  Smooth caramel malt with a little grain and solid, but mild pine hops.  Mild residual bitterness.  Good, but forgettable.

Draft pint at Anthonys, Harrisburg. Copper with a small ring of cream. Nose is earthy grain, caramel, toast and light citrus. Flavor is the same. Light-medium body is smoothly carbonated, balanced and an easy drinker.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Golden-amber body.. moderate sized offwhite head... good lacing... moderate retention

S: Solid citric and floral hop notes. Delicate malts.

T: A nicely crafted american blonde. Its got a fresh field feel to it. Between the citrus notes,the plentiful floral tones, the orchard fresh peach highlights and the bready-wheat like malts this is a nice beer.

M: Medium light body. Near ideal carbonation. A slightly lingering semi-dry finish is a treat.

O: A great session brew at 5% and a healthy dose of flavor.

Drinks nicely. Good hop quotient and could be close to sessionable. Good job.

Pours amber with a white head.  Aroma is caramel, citrus and florals.  Taste is sweet with a bitter finish.  Light mouthfeel with some stickyness.  Overall this was more reminiscent of an IPA then a cream ale.

Can.  Pours a murky dark gold with medium head.  The aroma is hops and spice, kind of like a hefeweizen.  The initial taste is bitter moving towards a spicy, lemony finish with a pleasant lingering aftertaste.  Not what I was expecting.  An OK beer.

Had it twice: cool to cold and in a stemmed pilsner glass, as recommended, and freezing cold and out of a can. The difference between the two was radical, not just incremental. Properly served, everything comes through: light but lively carbonation, thin but not too thin body, head the announces substance, an immediate taste of citrus that quickly mellows, receding to let the sharp bitters take over. Overall, very nicely balanced: even harmonious, as the label claims. If a cream ale is meant to taste close to a kolsh, though, this one isnt anywhere near. Not that theres anything wrong with that.

Can.  Sweet orange malt and citrus peel aroma.  Hazy golden yellow color with nice large, fluffy head.  Lightly sweet orange and moderately bitter grapefruit peel flavor.  Nice and unusual - only hoppy cream ale Ive ever had.

Draft at Michaels Bistro. Pours golden with a thin white head. Theres a slight hint of pine on the nose. Nice creaminess on the tongue. The finish has nice amounts of hop flavor. Its sort of a citrus tang. Nice version of the style.

12/30/11. 16oz can courtesy watson1977! Hazy orange pour with a nice khaki head that sticks for quite awhile and laces in soapy rings. Pretty solid aroma of citrusy, lemony hops with grass and a bit of seltzer water. Sweet, almost fruity flavor at first that shows watermelon, grass, and lingering dry hoppiness. Theres also a small aspect of metal and what hits me as alcohol in the flavor, though that doesnt seem right. Either way, a tasty surprise!

16 oz can. pours a brilliant orange tinged amber with an eggshell head. Sweet, light caramel and orange nose. Nice, light bready flavor, light tangerine/orange zest late. Finish is clean and slightly dry. Excellent sessionable sipper.

16 oz can.  Muddy orange with brief beige froth.  Nose is cooked cabbage, pine and candi; weird, almost offensive.  Medium light, moderate carb.  Taste maybe does cross the line; orange marmalade, stale caramel, tart lime juice and basil.  I thought this was OK on tap, what went wrong?

Tap.  Pours hazy amber with a medium, fizzy white head, medium retention with light lacing.  Aroma is biscuit and straw malt, light hops and fruity esters.  Flavor is moderate malt with medium hops and bitterness, light esters and a dry finish.  Light body, low warmth and carbonation.

Draft. Pours hazy amber with thin white head; minimal lacing. Aroma is caramel, malt, orange and sweetbread. Taste is sweet with notes of floral hops, orange peel, and malt. Light body and medium carbonation. Very smooth with a soft creamy taste.

16 oz. can from Grape & Gourmet.  Yellowish-orange pour with a foamy off-white head.  Aroma of tangerine, pineapple, passion fruit, and wet grass.  The taste is not as hop-forward as the aroma would lead you to believe; sweet lager-like malts actually complement the hops quite well.  Not bad for a cream ale.

Good sized bright white head of varying sized bubbles.  Nice hoppy aroma with some mandarin oranges, fresh cut grass and some light malty notes. Color is a dark orange.  Pretty thin body and palate with some sweet malts, more oranges, flowery bitterness and a soft mouthfeel.  Rather creamy in the mouth.  Guess that makes sense.  An ok brew.

16 oz can.  Pours a little darker than expected for a Cream Ale, very dark gold under a nice two inch frothy off-white head.  The nose is nicely hoppy with delicate floral hops, some light caramel maltiness below.  The flavor is quite hoppy for the style as well, just a nice cleansing bitterness to lift the slightly sweet bready malt.  Finishes with a lingering hoppiness.  Light bodied and very drinkable with nice light fizzy carbonation.  A pretty nice beer, simple and straight forward.

Tap @ DuMont Burger Aug 10. Cloudy orange pour with a short head which leaves a coarse lace. Medium body, pine and floral hop aromas, finely carbonated and a solid bread and caramel malt underpinning. A balanced ale with a smooth mouth feel. It’s spicy, complex and very sessionable. Another hit from Sixpoint!

sample on tap at Virgils, New York.
Thin white head.  Clear amber pour.  Nice

Can.  Orange-amber beer with a thin yet stoic blanket of foam.  The aroma is sweet indeed -- This drinks with a musty essence, like wet hops.  Makes me think of a rainy fall day in the forest.  (#4358, 11/20/2011)
Pours amber with a thick 1" head.  Nice aroma of light malt, yeast, hops and some raisins.  Light to medium palate with a smooth taste that is a bit creamy.

16 oz can courtesy of myspoonistoobig.  Thanks Michael.  Pours a cloudy copper amber with a small light tan head that has decent retention and leaves some light lacing.  The aroma is caramel, some breadiness as well as some light citrus.  The initial taste is sweet caramel, followed by some breadiness and some light grapefruit.  Light bodied.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Moderate carbonation.

From the 16 flo. oz. can stamped: Best Before 17Nov2011. It pours a medium amber with a slight haze and little to no head. A good dose of hops on the nose along with peaches and yeast. The body is above medium and creamy like i should be. Milly bitter hops and meaty fruits in the taste with a pleasant creaminess.  Likeable.

Meh...A so so beer, though I dont agree that this is a cream ale. Aroma was OK. Caramel malt with a hint of roastiness. Pour was a murky amber/light brown with a thin off white film for a head. Taste was a little disappointing. This beer is all malt driven. Notes of toffee and caramel are detectable but not very full or strong. Metallic aftertaste that is somewhat bitter, but not hoppy. Medium carbonation. Very average.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Can. Light nutty and caramel for the malt, moderate flowers and perfume for the hops, with wine, ginger and berries in the background. Head is small, fizzy, white with nolacing and is almost fully diminishing. Color is clear amber/orange. Flavor starts lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes with a hint of sweetness and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is medium, watery with a lively carbonation. Its was kind of said after smelling the complex and fruity aroma and the flavor just didnt hold up to it. Still a good drinker though.

Serving: 16 oz. can from State Line Liquors.  It pours a hazy deep gold color with a small, styrofoam like, white head.  The nose is a little grainy and sweet but it has a nice little floral and pine hop action too.  Some grain, but mostly hops with those floral and pine notes from the nose.  Thin on the tongue but thirst quenching with a dry finish.  I could pound this brew like nobodys business.  A great substitute for a lager.

Can/16oz - Pours a hazy golden amber in color with a medium white head that settled to a creamy covering over the beer.  Aroma was medium of biscuit malts, bready yeasts and citrus hops. Flavor is medium hoppy with plenty of bread dough malts.  Some small amount of diacetyl, but not enough to detract from the taste of the beer.  I like this way better than Genny Cream!

Can. Amber pour with a short tan head. Aroma is grainy and hoppy with tea leaves, soft citrus and light caramel. Taste is hoppy with soft citrus, tea leaves, light spicy hops, thinned caramel, and grains. Light bready malt as well. Body is medium with a soft bubbly carbonation. Ends with more tea leaves, caramel, grassy and spicy hops, light citrus and grains.

Can as pictured.  Pours basically a clear orange/brown.  Sorta sweet, not too bitter really.  Really almost tastes like a wheat beer, though I guess a cream ale makes sense.  Nothing to write home about, but not too bad either.

Hazy orange-amber with a nicely proportioned white head. The nose holds a rather nondescript malt profile- hints of caramel backup up by some spicy herbal hop notes. The flavor starts with bready malts, and quickly finishes with caramel, and orangepeel. Not much happening. A light to medium body sports low carbonation and a grainy but clean finish.
16oz can.  Pours a hazy gold with an average off-white head.  Aromas of bread and grass.  Flavor is bread, grass/wheat and a little caramel sweetness.  Not much like a cream ale, but decent.

Served on draft at Beer Run. Pours a hazy orange color with a medium sized creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of citrus hops. The taste is big citrus and leafy hops with a malty finish and a hint of vanilla. Medium bodied. Overhopped, not really like a cream ale, but still a good beer.

Can. Pour is hazy gold with a nice white head. Good lacing/some retention. Aroma is biscuit, light floral/citrus hops, earth. Taste is creamy with a small hop bite. Getting some light buttered biscuit (diacetyl?). Palate is creamy, light bodied, above average carbonation. Very nice easy drinking beer.
Slight spice and noble hop aroma with a fairly clean grain and noble hop palate. Good balance.

Sweet action!  I used to use that saying all the time freshman year of high school when I thought I was the next Will Smith, so I love the name.  16oz can thanks to cosmo4u.  Hazy orange in color with a small off-white head.  Citrus aroma with herbal and sweet malt notes.  Some tea/leafy aromas.  Flavor is nice, like a bitter/cream ale hybrid.  Sweet caramel, orange, grapefruit, and tea.  No unpleasant bitterness or strange aftertaste that cream ales can have.  Carbonation is somewhat tingly but after it subsides, the mouthfeel is silky smooth.  Overall, yeah, this beer is some sweet action.
can... murky orange with a light tan head... sweet yeasty nose with a bit of skunk... generic sweet, pretty boring, meh

Can from Half Time. Pours dark hazy amber with a few bubbles for head. Aroma is rather herbal. Med body. Flavor is tart. Maybe noble hop. Seems a little citric. Flavor is intense, but hard to pin down. Reasonably tasty, but hard to validate the style. Finishes more bitter than not.
Draft at Standard.  Cloudy orange color.  Aroma and taste of orange peel and citrus.  Decent.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2015 8/19/2015
I had the opportunity to try this beer again, Im told the recipe has been reworked a bit. Resinous, earthy, light oniony hop nose with plenty of toasted bready maltiness to back it up. Firm earthy resinous spicy hop flavor with the same maltiness to back it up nicely. Im not sure why both sites have this listed as a Cream ale, its more of a APA than anything, and its a damn fine beer if you get into the right frame of mind for it . Im glad I revisited this! My rating reflects this session. 
9/17/2011 Pours a slightly cloudy deep reddish amber color with a smallish fluffy white head that slowly dissipates to a cap. Smells of earthy herbal hops and biscuit bready malt. Hints of lemony dish soap turned me off a bit. Taste is malty but not a sweet as I had expected from a cream ale. Lots of bitter earthy hops keep this less balanced than the side of the can would lead you to believe. Medium body and carbonation level, slick almost sticky mouthfeel. This one grew on me as I drank it and as it warmed, but I really dont see the attraction here. Its not really a cream ale, but its a pretty good drinker.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2012 4-pack of tall cans. I wasnt sure what style this is, but it isnt really a cream ale. Hazy orange. The citrusy hops are quite prominent, and it isnt all that sweet (but hops are more for flavor/aroma than bittering). I dont get those yeasty flavors others do. It is quite good.

20110914  16oz can from 3rd Bass.  How odd that the last rating of this beer was from over a year ago.  At any rate, Im sure Ive had it before, maybe at TAP or something.... and that is what I was starting to write when I was accidentally on the page for Double Sweet Action.  This is a pretty cool diversion of a beer in nifty packaging.  Spicy character pervades in a way that seems almost to be Belgian yeastyish.  Refreshing despite mild sweetness and soft body.  Bitter though not dry.  Sweet/spice/citrus on seedy toasty bread, its really not an APA or hoppy amber, and I am quite enjoying this nearly on a revelatory level.  It doesnt hurt one bit that this and the Bengali Tiger cans I picked up are adorned with bits of amazing poetic verse.  I did not expect to be excited by either of these two beers, but with this one I am.  Cool.
16 oz. bottle with the ESBLS.  A copper brown pour with a thin layer of foam.  Kind of an earthy hoppy  aroma that is hard to find.  Tasted are soft hops and some toasty caramel that is faint.

500ml can. Hazy orange with an off-white head, nice lacing. Blend of sweet malt and hops, it of fruit and funky yeast. Taste is a little off in terms of balance between sour, bitter and sweet, very little carbonation considering the head - almost no head, little thin, slightly stale with a quick finish. Meh.

Pours a murky amber with an almost non existent white top.  Aroma is a mix of sweetness, sourness and bitterness.  Taste is a slightly off balance with sweet hop with a mild bitterness then almost a sourness that is a little off putting.  A metallic aftertaste that lingers in the mouth.  Thanks to spinrsx for this.
Can. Pours clear gold. White head. Nose of creamy hops, sweet malt, lightly buttered biscuit and light caramel. Some herbal notes. Medium body.

This beer is not a cream ale.  It is almost a spiced APA.  Poured from a 16 oz can I got from brew brothers. Strong olfactory presence; sweet and rotten at the same time, weird candy like as well.  Big strong hop presence, wants to be an IPA but the maltiness is there and forces it to back off in a cloyingly sweet way.  Large and in charge this sweet brew is.  Seems like much more than 5% fer sure.  Its almost like it wasnt fermented enough to get the sugars out er somethin. Yucky kucky mucky.  Reminds me of many amber ales that are overdone and experimented with.  Cloying sweetness overcomes the palate at time.  Finish is unique hard old style candy laced with alky. Long bitter finish of an amber that wants to be an IPA, wew.  Quite dissapointing to the pale lager lover.  The sweet may be a misnomer in the name of this brew, its not really sweet per se, its more like alky laced somthing or other.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: hazyOn tap at Croxleys Ales in Farmingdale. Pours hazy golden orange with white head. Aromas of sweet caramel malts, light citrus, and biscuity notes. Flavors of light spices, belgain yeast, bit of citrus hops, and caramel malts. Drinkable but nothing special.
Poured a dark golden color and was hoppy on the nose. Tastes slightly bitter, with some herbs/spices. Pretty good from a can.

Clear and deep golden in color. Light, hoppy aromas. Flavor is of grass. Spice, more grass. I just finished mowing the lawn... na. Not this. Some malts in the middle. Then, more grass. Very herbal. Not that great. Certainly overhyped and overpriced too.

Sampled from a 16 oz can this beer poured a hazy orange color with a huge soapy beige head that lingered forever and left some lacing. The aroma was sweet creamed corn, light perfume and hints of grapefruit and catbox. The flavor was tangy caramel, creamed corn, faint grapefruit and undertones that were must, earthy and herbal. Medium finish. Medium body. Eh.
Auburn pour. Nice nose of grassy hop and sweet malt. Beautiful further balance to of hops and malt in the flavor, with really nice smoothness in the mouthfeel. Very tasty.

A clear copper body that had a slight carbonation to it similar to mineral water.  A thin white head that had no retention.  Aroma was nice and interesting some base malts were distinguishable but were over shadowed by pine hops and a spice not that wasnt sure if it was  clove or nutmeg but along those lines.  Initial flavor had a peach note to it mixed with some hops and spices.  Body was light and thin.

473 mL can, Long Island, NY. Pours cloudy amber with small head.  Smells fruity, hint of citrus and malt. Taste is slightly sweet with citrus and hoppy bitterness.  Hopness is mild. I am not a big hop guy and I really liked this one. Awesome summer beer.

Tap at some Brooklyn bar.  Mildly dry with a nice hoppy note.  Good caramel backbone.  Its not a very complex beer, but its easy to drink.  The grain flavor is sorta musty.  Its a pretty good summer beer.

473 ml can. 5.2%. Brooklyn, NY.
Clear dark amber colour with small off-white head.
Fresh fruity hops in aroma. Strong malt and strong bitterness.

Bitterish aftertaste.

A: The pour is a slightly cloudy orange color with a fluffy white head and minimal lacing.

S: Starts off with a nice bready sweetness and a bit of biscuit malt.  A light floral and citrusy hop aroma with just a faint caramel note.  There might even be a little bit of honey to it.

O: Certainly one of the better cream ales Ive ever had and a very nice, easy to drink beer.  Perfect for the summer.

pours somewhat hazy orange with a lasting thin white head and lots of lacing.  aroma is sweet with a notes of tangerine and other tangy fruit.  taste has note of tropical fruit as well as fresh hops. the mouthfeel is creamy but also wet and refreshing.  finish is mildly bitter but the sweetness remains.  a subtle but enjoyable session beer.

Growler.  Pours clear dark orange with a rising effervescent spiral of bubbles, and a large creamy light beige head.  Aromas of sweet orangepeel, citrus, mild Belgian yeast, and grass.  The flavor is mild lemon and orange, light tartness and bitter seeds, some Belgian yeast, and maybe some mango funk.  Nearly creamy mouthfeel.  One-dimensional, but pretty good.  [750]

hops. slaughterhouse, Earth and spice in this brew that has some appreciable sweetness...and spice. creamy,slick and frothy the brew seems a bit brown and dirty with full enough body and nice genuine hop character that is apparent but under intense competition. birch beer and root beer like the best i ever had like it. extra points for the brewers words on the can that harken the saying "that makes sense to me". $3.00 the 16OZ can in Manhattan the center of the Earth NYC.
