Can via trade.  Clear orange pour, average carbonation and an aroma of sweet creamy orange hops.  Flavor was also orangy hop oil and a finished with a slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Really liked this, but didnt really understand how this could be a cream ale (tasted more like an IPA)

Poured from a 1 pint can into a dimpled mug.

The color is a cloudy dark orange with a finger of foamy white head that is some pretty quickly and does not leaves any thing behind.

The smell is pretty hoppy at first with some citrus flavor and a touch of fresh cur grass.

The taste is hoppy but sweetness that is hidden in the background with the hoppy green flavor. There is some buttery flavor that is there briefly but gone.

The feel of this beer is a little crisp but dry as well. It goes down easy with a slight aftertaste that is nice.

Pours clear orange with white head thanks to Greg, aroma has notes of pine, grass, some slight biscuit notes.  Taste is nice pine and grass with biscuit and slight fruit, finishing slightly dry and bitter for sure.  Its good, but not a cream ale.

[Can] shared by greg. Thanks! Pours clear gold with a smallish white head. Aroma is quite hoppy for a cream ale, caramel, fruity esters, grainy. Flavor is light hop, grain, light bitterness. Long finish. How is this a cream ale?
Pour is a light orange color deep a deep shade of gold. Nose is of some light spices. Taste is rather interestingly spicy, but like gingerbread. Smooth and refreshing, good beer.

Pours muddy light brown.  small head.  Really has some slight spicy and estery notes in the nose like a belgian ale.  Flavor has some ginger bread characteristics.  Pretty easy drinking beer but its not my style at all. Really glad to try this thanks to phillybeer7779
Very light drinkable beer.  Hops are more prevalent then i anticipated.  Not too much to say about this pleasant yet boring pale-cream ale.
UPDATED: JUL 9, 2011 Piney tasty full flavored cream ale. Tastes more like a pale ale than a cream ale. Maybe thats why its the second best rated cream ale

Can...  Poured amber-ish/orange with a white-ish head.  Pretty hop forward, some earthy, herbal spiced tones.  Parsley, garden-like herbs.  Citrus and pine from the hops.  A little bit of a honey sweetness and decent malt backing.
Tap: Clear gold color with a white ring head. Sweet aroma of malts followed by a grapey taste with a wheaty aftertaste.  Ok.

16 oz can from EZ. Poured a hazy sunburnt orange with an average to large foamy white head. Aroma is dull, grains and a hint of dried out orange rind. Body is fuller with bubbly carbonation and a creamy feel. Flavor like the aroma is dull and boring grain and citrus. Not much going on here.

Bottle. Pours amber with a bit of haze and a thin white head. The aroma is a very interesting combination of sweet malt, grassy hops, and some herbal, grassy notes. Medium to light bodied with a light sweetness (not as much as you might think with the word Sweet in the name), not a ton of flavor. Very light bitterness on the finish with some more grassy, herbal notes. Not terrible, but not a big fan.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2011 Had this out of a can at a BBQ.  Nice hop to malt balance.  tasted to me more like a pale ale even though this is classified as a cream ale.  Malt flavor was nice, caramel notes.  hop flavor wasnt over the top, spricy notes.  Dry.  Not too bad

Pours a golden yellow with minimal head. Aroma of honey and pine. Taste us orange rhines and pine spice. Good blend of sweet/tart then spicy and bitter. Leaves the tounge crisp and clean with a bit of a sour metallic lingering flavor.

Pours gold into a Sam glass.  White head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Sweet kettle corn and funk aromas. Medium bodied with sweet carnival candy and funk. Dry, lasting bitter finish.

Pours a rusty orange with a quickly dissipating head of the bubbly goods.  Nose is sweet and buttery with lots of malt.  Taste is smooth, a clean wash of malted cream, slightly sweet like cream soda with just a hint of bitterness in the finish.  Simple and refreshing, though the sweetness is a little too much after a few cans.

On tap. Poured a deep near clear amber with a thick cream color head that dissipated slowly to the edges and laced. Aroma was full of a strong sweet biscuit note with backing sweet grains and a hint of light fruits. Flavor was similar with strong biscuit throughout that had underlying sweet grains and light fruit notes. Bit sweet for me.

A Sim rate (can from Whole Foods NYC): Aroma is malty with sweetness but really no finesse. Bitter initial hit but unfortunately the sweetness doesnt back you up this time. Its not offensive but its really not balanced or sophisticated. Really not the end to my batchelorette weekend that I was hoping for.

A - Pours a cloudy copper-orange color with a finger of frothy off-white head. The head fades down to a thin layer leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - The aroma is a mix of sweet malts and grains. There is also just a touch of hops and some bready aroma mixed in as well.

T - The beer starts off with some sweet grain and malt flavors and just a touch of hops. Through the middle, some sweeter malts and some bready flavors come through. The finish is a mix of sweet grains and corn with just a touch of hops that linger.

M - Medium-light bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels really smooth and avoids feeling watery. Also does not feel empty at all. The finish is fairly clean.

D - Duper drinkable. The flavors stay interesting and complex enough while never feeling heavy. On the flip side, it also avoids feeling empty and watered down.

On tap at Capones, Norristown. Bright orange/brown pour with a moderate carbonation to it. Nose is soft and floral, with citrus, sugar, and a slight herbal tweak. Body is thick, creamy, and lively, with plenty of substance for style. The flavors are a combination of sweet and dry citrus, making this an almost IPA-ish cream ale. Fairly interesting and I enjoyed it.
Sample at Julios Spring Beerfest. Wasnt a big fan of this one. It was OK for the style I suppose just not great overall. Reminded me of a typical macro.

On tap at Capones this past weekend. Served in a mini snifter.

Right off the bat, Ill say that I was quite excited to try this one, as its been the number one Cream Ale for quite some time nice. Since most beers in this style are pretty awful, I was anxiously anticipating trying a good one. This delivered. Bigtime.

Pours a clear golden color with a really nice white head. Good retention and some swell lacing. Good so far. The nose was really quite faint. There was a touch of floral hops with a bit of breadiness. Pretty tame. Really tame, in fact. The taste countered with an explosion of flavor. Perfect balance between light bready/grainy sweetness and floral and herbal hops. Nice and delicate. Very refreshing. Best cream ale, by far. The feel backed that up. It was nice and crisp with a solidly bitter finish. Really well done. Enthusiastic thumbs up, Sixpoint.

$7.99 growler just filled at Brew York (in Duane Reeds) on 72nd and Broadway--I cant think of the last time I paid so little for a growler.  Slightly hazy medium gold with a one finger creamy off-white head, fading to a thick film.  Aroma has some floral hops with a bit of hair spray, and then some honey and toasted grain. Semi-dry finish with bitterness peaking at a 3.  Body is a little watery, light smooth carbonation.  Not too bad at this price point, definitely drinkable.

text: Pours an orange color with a hop aroma with some toasted malts.  Lots of hops in the flavor-which was a surprise.  Also had some toasted malt and grain flavor.  Not bad, but not typical.

Sorry to rate this one relatively low, but I had the pint on draft at the Meatball Shop, NYC - against the spicy food, Sweet Action did not stand up very well. Shaker pint draft at Peculier Pub in New York City.  Pour is hazed orange, with a smallish off white head.  Very unfiltered looking, almost cask like. Had at mcrossens.with ashley. Pour is a hazy body caramel. little head. No lace. Aroma of apricot, white grapes and apple.  Flavor is sweet malts with hints of white grape. Full body and nice lay on the tongue.
hazy golden amber, small head, toasty light hop, a little citrus, creamy body, medium body, decent flavor accented by some light fruits, very mild aroma
growler from Bowery Whole Foods.  pours a light brown.  Interesting taste.  very light mouthfeel, almost watery (but not in a bad way).  An interesting style.

Tap. Pours a bright cloudy brown color with a nice thick head. Tastes of cream, pine and pine. Smell is citrusy with malty backbone. Nice hop and bitter balance.nothing crazy going on here, but decent.

tap: surprised this is only averaging a 3.34. Light copper pour into (unfortunately) a plastic cup, despite this head retention was still pretty good. Sweet, lemony citrus flavors, malted candy, caramel, some sticky brown + cane sugars. Not cloying at all though, as its got a nice hop balance. Not very bitter, but lovely florals. Rich creamy body.

Tap at Fontanas. Wow, holy mother this was good. The pour was an orange amber with a rocky, dense, yellowish head with great retention and sticky lace. Aroma of fresh citrus hops, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, ruby red grapefruit. Taste has a fresh, quenching maltiness, fresh peach, and oily hops to balance a toffee-laden sweetness. English malt characters abound but American, fresh, oily hops dominate. The body has faint grapefruit tartness that balances sweet English toffee and sweet peach. I was telling my friends that the best IPAs are ones where there is no bitterness, only quenching freshness and balance. This is "cream ale" but it would do well as an IPA. Find me a better cream ale and I will probably explode spontaneously.
Tap. Poured a cloudy orange. Nose is sweet hoppy and malty. Flavor is as the nose.Big hops, Nice malts with yes, some real but totally non cloying sweetness. Nice
Very nice pine, citrus aroma. The beer is cloudy orange with a big foamy head. The flavor is malty sweet up front but mostly bitter hops at the back. Very nice dry long lasting finish. Good stuff.
Light citrus aroma. Cloudy orange color with a small white head. Light bitter beginning developing some sweetness in the finish.
aroma and taste is lemony citrus. there is also a bitterness that is borderline harsh. the color is orange. light to medium body. overall a good session beer.

Copper body with a small white head.  The aroma is dominated by simple hops and some amber malt.  Strange hop quality on the flavor--pretty bitter, but no real hop flavor.  The bitterness works very strangely with the malt, in a not so good type of way.  Its generally just a kind of unpleasant bitter bite.  Overall: alright, but a bit strange and questionable.
Very nice creamy pale/ipa. lots of nice hoping aboard warm balanced malting. Great food compliment, tasty

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2011 On tap at unos in neshaminy. Theres a mild aroma of light hops and grain.   Taste is watery grain, minimal flavor, a little banana ester/yeast. Light body. Not sure I would have this again.

Tap @ DuMont Burger. Cloudy orange pour with a short head which leaves a coarse lace. Medium body, pine and floral hop aromas, finely carbonated. A balanced ale with a smooth mouth feel. Its spicy, complex and very sessionable. Another hit from Sixpoint!
Hazy gold with white head.  Aroma is a bit like honey graham cracker.  Taste is similar with light and sourness and toast into the finish.  $5/pint

On tap somewhere in NYC.  Pours a light orangey-yellow.  with a finger of head.  Tangy aroma of lemon.  Mouthfeel is light with a good amount of carbonation.  Taste is very clean and leans more towards an APA than a cream ale.  A good amount of hops for this style.  Lots of citrus and a little bit of pepper too.  A very, very good beer.  No wonder its all over the city; easy to drink but good, complex taste too!

Draught. Mild fruity aroma. Muddy dark amber colour. Small creamy white head. The flavour starts off with a good fruitiness, turning quite bitter. Hint of yeast in the finish. Low carbonation. Like a good, flavourful cask ale.

[Draft @ EB+B] Lightly hazy golden color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of grains, toast, and light citrus.  Taste of toffee, toast, light citrus, and a semi-sweet finish.

On tap at Old Bay - New Brunswick, NJ. Pours a hazy clearish mid-golden, with minimal head. Again, served icy cold in a heavy frosted mug, with no head space. Aroma is faint, but of light sweet malt and a touch of hops, dry. Flavors are good. At this temperature and paired with Crawfish Etouffee, its not bad. Theres a nice edge of fresh hop flavors that comes across and above-average bitterness. Its enjoyable and refreshing. Maybe one of the better Cream Ales Ive ever had.
UPDATED: JAN 31, 2012 Golden brown, hoppy, sweet and smooth. A bit thin, but really a perfect summer beer. Great on tap. Very nice out of the can too.

From a tap poured a straw color with a fair amount of head.  Nice sweet hoppy flavor with a quick finish.
On draught at Village Pour house, very drinkable, smooth and prefect for a relaxing beer with a burger.

On tap at Rubys oyster House in Rye, NY.  pours is a amber with soft white head.  taste is of malt and slight brown sugar.  There was honey in the description but i didnt get any.  Slightly bitter and a pretty good pairing with the pan fried oysters i ordered

Served on tap at Rembrandts.

Pours a dark amber orange color with dark burnt orange hues when held to a light source and a two finger frothy, soapy head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glass with lacing.

Slightly hoppy aroma with hints of pine needle, lactic cream, grass, light crisp fruit, biscuit and pale malt.

Slightly dry, hoppy mediu body which is on the fuller end of the spectrum. Creamy with hints of crisp light fruit, dry piney hops, pale malt, biscuit, apple, pear, sweet lactic creaminess and a dry earthy bitter hop finish. Excellently balanced and dangerously drinkable. I wasnt expecteing much from this beer but other than the aroma I really enjoyed it. Recommended!

A light, hazy amber orange with a thin off-white head that persists.  The nose is heavy on the brown sugar and malt.  Shes heavily bitter, with a medium-full, smooth feel and dense carbonation.  Orange peel and some rind, with a citrusy hop sting that feels a bit peppery.  A good beer, not mind blowing, but an interesting and (for me) a sessionable brew.

(Old BA rate - tap)
Poured with a half-finger of white head. Curtains of lacing toward the beginning of the sample, and dies down toward the end, though. Slightly hazy light orange-gold color. Sweet biscuity/bready malt and light yeastiness. Followed up by a bit of hop bitterness. Very reflective of the aroma; sweet-sour with the malt and yeast that provides a nice pinch of flavor; biscuit-like doughiness; mild earthy hop bitterness. Mediumish MF; a little oily and creamy as well. Nice lighter carbonation. Pretty solid here. Fantastic drinking. A bit heavy in body for the style, but doesnt detract from the satisfying and quaffable nature of this brew. Overall, I find this to be an excellent session brew and one that I have visited, and will hopefully be able to continue visiting. (Well not anymore since I live in Switzerland now)
Drank from a pint glass from the tap at the Peculiar Pub, NYC.  Totally average beer; weak malt and hop flavors that never really shine through, clean aftertaste.

Tap at Peculier Pub. Pretty good. Pours a light gold with a medium, pure white head. Nose of earthy malts. Flavor has some light bitterness along with some mildly sweet malts. Medium in body in smooth.

On tap at a small BBQ in NJ. The pour was a nice copper amber color with a good two finger head of lacing that was slightly offwhite. The taste was a little bitter for me and tasted a little more like a cream stoudt than an ale. Not bad but not great.

Had on-tap at Capones. Served in a tulip glass.

THe appearance of this beer reminds me of a Hopslam. A very hazy bright orange color with a thick puffy 2 finger almost pure white head. Great lacing as it really sticks to the glass.

Smell, smell is west coast hops, some sweetness from caramel malts. A little breadiness.

Pretty balanced flavor. Some bread like caramel malt sweetness up front, with a small amount of hop bitterness in the form of white grapefruit on the finish.

Nice smooth light bodied. A dry finish and would be very nice on a warm day.

Over all a pretty decent blond ale. Not a huge amount of flavor but its easy to drink and is pretty refreshing. Not a bad beer.

Pint on tap at Croxleys. Pours a hazy dark golden color with moderate head. Aroma is rather fruity, predominantly citrus, with some hops as well. Very fresh and some floral aromas in there too. Taste is balanced and not as bitter as the smell would indicate as there is more sweet maltiness instead of bitterness. Palate is smooth and has a clean aftertaste. Good option to pair with food or just to drink.
On tap at The Half Pint, NYC. Murky copper body with sweet and fruity nose. Same in the taste, quite sweet. Gets maltier and then spicier. Not much cream noticeable.

Once poured, releases a fruity aroma with the addtiion of alt and a grassy hop.  Very cloudy with a thin head of off-white color.  Taste as action packed as a lively football game sweet meeets bitter.  Palate leaves the wounded on the field and a long victorious finish.  Hops are attacked by maltiness goodness.
Amber-orange body with fine creamed head. Mild fruity hoppiness in the bouquet translates to fruity hop flavor across a mild malting.  Moderately fruity and grainy. One of the best of the style.

On tap at Bukowski Tavern, Boston MA, 28 September 2009. Well, well, well. I just had a cream ale without even realizing it. And the best one there is apparently. Amber colour. Scant head. Hops dont make much initial impression but creep up on you. Quite firm mouthfeel. Relatively straightforward but decent, refreshing drinking.
Light citrus and more floral to earth hop aroma.  Flavor similar.  Pretty bland overall

Earthy pine hops. Pours clear amber with little head. Little sweet malty backbone then an ugly bitter finish. Taste of a little milky sweetness but am surprised its a cream ale. Decent carbonation. I cant say this is the best cream ale but still a solid beer. Give me a Hales cream ale any day.

I was wondering what kind of beer this was and upon seeing that it is a cream ale, I am not at all surprised. Pours a cloudy copper color. Has a pretty fruity nose. Tastes fruity at the front and I almost mistook it for a fruit beer. Then finishes off with a yeasty finish. Some hops in there. Rather on the sweet side of things.
Pours orange yellow with a white head.  Mild hop/orange aroma.  Light, sweet flavor with just the right amount of hops.  I really enjoyed this.
Growler from Bierkraft.  Hazy copper with lasting head and lace.  Aromatic herbal hop and fruity nose.  Mild fruity malt with medium aromatic citrus hop finish.  Fairly light and quaffable.  Not bad.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2011 growlerpours a rich white head that laces and copper color.  Aroma is medium malt, spice/resin hops.  Taste is sweet light malt-caramel, herbal hops up front then mid/late palate very thin for the first pint.  By second pint a bit thin/light body.  
Can for rerate-thanks JamesMr Porhouse

Water Taxi Beach: The name alone, Sweet Action, is worth drinking.  Poured by a wreckless short order cook, had to fight to get a top off to replace the 2 inch head he left! Anyway, a amber pour, no cloudiness, slightly off white, lasting head.  Im not so familiar with cream ales, although this is good... smooth, mild taste, not too heavy on the hops at all, somewhat bitter, but overall mild.  Easily drinkable, does coat your mouth more than an American style ale will.

Draft, A very hoppy copper-colored beer. Nose is hops and a little citrus. Pretty bitter for a cream ale, tasted more like a pale ale. Its smooth and medium bodied, but its got a peppery bite to it, instead of that thick cream flavor.

On tap at The Pool in Brooklyn.  Pours golden with a white head.  Smells hoppy with a fair amount of citrus.  Tastes a bit skunky, with a bit of grapefruit pulp, and caramel.  Not that creamy at all, but the result isnt half bad.

Im not a big fan of cream ales, but this offering is pretty decent.  I found it on draft at the Craft Ale House.  This beer is extremely refreshing.  Its one of those you could enjoy after an afternoons work out in the yard.  The beer pours a clear and bright golden color with a sticky white head.  The head leaves a generous amount of lacing along the glass.  The nose is full of fresh citrus notes like lemon and orange and a bit of a flowery tone.  The body is smooth and drinkable.  The flavors are crisp and quite refreshing as well.  Some notes included were grass, citrus, peach and bread.  The bready notes imparted a nice balance on the beer.  The finish is very crisp and balanced.  Overall a pretty nice cream/blonde ale.

Draft at SoHo Park. Poured a clear medium orange color. The head was creamy and off white. Smelled of pale malts and pleasant light citrusy hops. Light bodied and moderately carbonated. The flavors mimicked the aromas. There was some very mild bitterness at the end. The citrusy American hop nose and flavor made this beer more reminiscent of an American pale ale than any cream ale Ive tried.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2011 Draft at Capones.  Pours hazy deep gold with off-white head that forms great lace.  Nose is hopcitrus, pale malt, apricotty fruit, peppery.  Tastes smooth, creamy, with hopcitrus, peppery spice and a smooth finish.  One of the best cream ales I have ever quaffed.

Tap at Capones.  Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a creamy off white head that laced.  Aroma of orange peel, floral, cereal grains and touch of caramel.  Flavor of orange peel, citrusy hops, cereal grains, great creamy mouthfeel and bready.  Really nice hop flavor without all the extreme bitterness.

Draft @Good Night Irenes  Pours a clear golden with a good lasting white head.  The head produces good lacing.  Has a nice aroma of pineand spruce hops.  Also a touch of pepper.  Has a smooth flavor with some vanilla hints.  Well balanced with a lighter body.  Has a good hoppy taste and a solid aftertaste.  Good carbinationa nd a good mouthfeel.  Has an oily texture.  This is fairly good beer.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2010 Draft at Macs tavern with Linh. Pours a nice amber body with decent haze. Aroma is vanilla and slight hop. Mouthfeel is creamy with notes of vanilla and slight hop in the background.  A solid brew.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2009 On tap @ Rattle n Hum, NYC.   I had no idea this was a cream ale.  Assumed it was a experimental type blonde ale or something.  Noticeable vanilla notes.  I really liked this, good all around.  (Also enjoyed this in LIC with CUJO during a beach volley ball game.  Rating left the same)
Draft.  Pours a pale golden body with a white head.  Some light earth, hints of lemon and citrus, mild malt bill with a dry finish.

From a growler at Bierkraft. Pours a copper color with a slight head. Aroma of toast, grassy hops and slight spiciness from the yeast. Medium to light medium mouthfeel. Sweet on the front with slight bitterness and a smooth dry finish. Not bad.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2009 Bell House in Brooklyn. Probably the best way to describe this beer is take a #9, subtract a tad of the apricot and add in some hops. Personally, I dont think this beer tastes anything like a cream ale, but thats a good thing.

On tap at the Peekskill Brewery.  Pours a hazy deep amber with a white head dark enough to be almost tan.  Some malt on the nose, but otherwise not much else.  Body is sweet and malty, with a note of pineapple.  Finishes with a gentle bitterness and a note of vanilla.
On draft at the Barcade.  Pours a murky caramel with a tiny white head.  Aroma of faint citrus hops, wheat and grains.  Taste of tangy bitter citrusy hops and grains.  Average.

750ml  Growler acquired in trade from goldtwins. Poured a deeper and hazy golden color with an aveeraged sized off white head. Aromas of citrus, caramel, a little bready and lightly earthy. Tastes of the same breadiness, caramel, and lighter citrus. Light lacing left on the glass. Not a bad session ale and quite tasty for a Cream Ale.
HAD IT IN A GROWLER. IT POURS WITH A THICK CREAMY HEAD WITH A NICE COPPER COLOR. HAD A CITRUS FRUITY TASTE POSSIBLY PEACH  WITH A HOPPY BITTER AFTERTASTE.

Had this on draft.The appearance was 
copper-straw color with a decent white head.The aroma was dominated by hops and pine.That is how the flavor was as well,plus also some citrus,meduim body and light malt.Pretty good.

Growler. Pours a clear orange red with a very small ring of white head. Aroma of sweet malt, fruits, especially raspberry and peach. Flavor is pretty similar with lots of sweet jam flavors, mostly peach, coming through. Some floral and citrus hops in the finish. Light bodied, not much going on here. A pretty chill beer.

Growler. Aroma of citrus and piny hops on a bready, caramel malt base. Same, distinct hop notes in the flavor balanced nicely with the malt. Didnt find it overly sweet as some have, just nice malt to go with the hops. Very enjoyable.

The aroma was immediate floral hops.  The appearance was copper color, strong white head.  The flavor had some sweetness, but was dominated by the hops, mainly citrus on the tongue.  The finish was nice, clean and  bitter.  Not bad at all.
On tap at the Empire BrewFest in Syracuse. Decent aroma of hops, piney hops. It’s kind of sweet but not overly so. A good cream ale but I probably would not buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: On tap, was a transparent medium dark copper.  Aroma of pine and citrus.  Head was pretty decent.  Palate very wet and fairly thin, but not detracting.  Flavor was sweet up front but transitioned to a nice deep bitterness, a little dirty.  sweetness is less noticeable as you continue drinking and didn’t go well at all with my lombardi’s pizza.  Overall, thoroughly enjoyed it before pizza came, would definitely get again.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2008 Straw colored with slight malt aroma.  Flavor is slightly sweet with a dry finish.  Those looking for a lighter style brew would find this to be a good option.  On tap at The Shep.
Clear copper in color with a white head. Caramel citrusy hoppy aroma. Citrusy hoppy sweet flavor. Caramel notes. Medium bodied. Finish is sweet. Decent beer.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2011 This is a hoppy blonde ale, with citrus and some sweetness.  The flavor develops and changes as it passes along the palate.  Revised downward in 2011 when I had it from one of their minikegs (i.e. cans).  Pretty straightforward, basic ale - not as interesting as when I first had it.
Pours a clear copper. Aroma of some citrus with some caramel and bread. Flavor is somewhat citrusy sweet with some hop backbone to carry you along.

Draft at MacGregors in Rochester. Pours hazy brown with a thin off white head. Lightly sweet aroma with notes of apple, chestnut, caramel and hops. Medium body. Flavor is similar to the aroma but with a more pronounced fruity note. Pretty good.

On tap @ Hop Devil in NYC.  This is a cream ale?  Its far too good for that label.  Pours clear copper with a good sized light tan head.  The aroma has lots of hops that have floral traits and are smooth and soft along with lightly sweet malt.  Medium crisp body with moderate carbonation.  The taste starts off very hoppy with spiciness and pine.  It starts off crisp and then gets resiny.  Some cream ale malt is detectable in the background, but this is definitely a hop-fronted beer.  The finish is resiny and hoppy ~ no surprise there.  A very good cream ale.

Tap at Hop Devil.  Golden amber with decent big bubble head.  Muted aroma of citrus grapefruit/lemon and herbal/floral hops with caramel, bready malt.  Mild flavor is similar with some additional peach/apricot fruit notes.  Beer flavor amplifies at the finish which is citrus hoppy and dry.  Thin to medium bodied.
On tap at MacGregors in Henrietta.  A deep orange colored beer with a thin layer of white cream, courtesy of the tap.  The aroma and flavor are simple and sweet.  It was easy to drink, but boring.

On tap from Daves Bellport Beer & Soda.  Pours an amber gold with a creamy linen white head that lasted until mid-glass.  The aroma was filled with lots of juicy citrus, very nice!  The flavor was more bitter than flavorful with a weak malt backbone.  This beer lacked the smoothness and mouthfeel I think of in a cream ale.  Way over-hopped in my opinion.  Not a bad beer, but not what I expected.

Had this from the tap in Brooklyn. Go figure. Anways, not a good beer.  Pours a golden hue, with a decent froth of head.  Aroma is barely there, but has some aspects of cookie dough.  Palate is dead, really.  Nothing going on, too sweet and simple for me. No thanks
On tap.  Pours a copper color with a tan head.  Aroma is fruity hops with malt and vanilla notes.  Taste is the same, with the beer remaining pretty smooth throughout.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. My first encounter with Sixpoint. Ok. Expected more. Seemed more of a weak APA to me. Mild bitterness, mild fruitiness. Mild toasted malt. Mildly drinkable

Tap @ Coles.  Light copper, thin tan head.  Nose is kinda english powdery fruit (it makes sense to me.)  Flavor is lightly tart malt, some peaches, english hops, tea.  Medium toasty malt in the finish.
On-tap at Coles.  A creamy IPA.  Lots of C-hop aroma and vanilla maltiness.  Creamy head on medium golden soapy head, fresh. Really good hoppy flavour.

On Cask but I have had it on draft many times. No head on cask but nice color. At Beech Tree in Potown. 20oz pint, not an imperial style pint, no curves, for 4.00. Pretty nice. Orange red brown yellow golen yum. Aroma light and fruity, raspberry and peach. Taste sweet, creamy, very good on cask.
Draft.  I must have had a bad keg because i found this rank smelling with some nasty hops.  I will avoid.

Off the tap pours a whirlwind of bubbles. Nose is very sweet hops. Flavor is a slightly subdued hop experience. At least subdued from the hop bomb comparitable aspect. It is mildlyfirm with pine attributes. Subtle citrus tones on the body as a whole. Fel is smooth and slightly thick on the liquid. Overall a good drinker. More subdued that some of Sixpoints hop head creations.

growler form whole foods on 2nd ave/bowery
sweet malty aroma tan golden color some hops in the nose decent balance in the taste with light hops giving way the the sweet carmael maltyness

Draft@ Rocky Sullivans in Red Hook Brooklyn the bar next door to Sixpoints.  Porus copper with a thin off white head.  The nose is sweet and malty.  It tastes sweet, light and matly, a bit of a pear taste coming through as well.  Its really smooth and damn drinkable.
I thought this was an awesome cream ale.  I bought this from a growler at Bierkraft and let me tell you it had some awesome cream elements and a very nice hop base to wrap it up.  OUTSTANDING

I found this on tap at Canterbury Ales in Huntington, NY where I went for a pint while waiting to meet a friend at Fazs Tex-mex. I enjoyed the brazen hops in it and mistook it for an IPA at first. Very easy to drink but it took a moment to resonate with the cream elements. Possibly it was too cold.
In a glass at Bubbies, Tribeca, NYC, Zero head, witha still, unbeerish, appearance in bright orange.  Strong taste of the hops, mayvbe some grapefruit and caramel...  Whiskey-like palette.

Tap at Lombardis New York....and yes it is the best pizza in the world....(that coming from a guy from NJ). Mostly clear amber with 1 finger white head. Malt aroma with a slight hop. Taste is refreshing, some sweet malts, slight creamy texture with a slightly bitter hop finish. Good compliment to the world class pizza.

Druaght.  Slightly hazy amber color with a frothy off-white head.  Left ruler- straight stripes of lacing.  Light malty aroma with floral and citrus hops, with an additional fruity note, like apple, peach and/or melon. Fruity and slightly sweet biscuity malt flavor with a fair dose of citrusy hops.  Medium to full bodied with lively carbonation.  Even discounting my pro-Sixpoint bias, a very fresh and satisfying brew.
Draught at Five Point restaurant, NYCHazy amber color. Simple Pale Ale, with some malt/caramel, but poor hopping and this one as well with the dirty water / tap water flavor.

Tap.  Pours an orangish-honey color with a thin, soapy white head.  Subtle aroma, probably a bit too cold: hops, sweet malts, citrus, resiny, like a baby IPA.  Slightly floral.  Nice flavor, easy to drink.  Slightly acidic (lemon/lime) with a nice sweet body and a lightly bitter, hopped finish.  Not huge on flavor but hugely easy to drink.  Went great with the pizza at Lombardis in SoHo.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 Pours an orangey golden white head which becomes lacing. The aroma is very nice of lemony sherbert. Theres definitly flowery flavors, and a slightly bisquity background. A very smooth lemon sherbert-like sweetness is present throughout with a citrusey slightly bitter finish. A very balanced and drinkable cream ale.

Pale amber beer, creamy thick white head that is very persistent.  Very fresh toasted malt backbone.  A bit of peachy fruit over the top of the sweet malts.  Flavour is substantially hoppier than I would have guessed from the nose.  Tropical and fruity with light grapefruit and citrus that nicely match the sweet peachy esters.  Lovely pale ale.

on tap at the "i" bar, manhattan.  didnt know what style this was, and it stumped me!  color was a pale amber with a thick off-white/light tan dimply head.  aroma is sweet like honey water and hops.  flavor was honeysuckle malt and flowery mild hops.  pretty interesting take on the style.

Cream ale... interesting. I didnt know what I was getting myself into when ordering this beer -- no one seemed to have any idea what style it was -- and when drinking it I was having a lot of trouble pinning down the style. I noticed some lager characteristics but noticed it was still very fruity and pretty rich, and certainly couldnt come up with a lager style to match, so I ended up hesitantly labelling it an EPA, even though I did notice a slight amount of grapefruit (American) hop aroma. The aroma was very perfumy with carribean fruit punch. Pretty rich malts in the taste, some munich style vegetably flavor, and earth finishing hops. Now that I think about it, Cream Ale is the perfect designation for a beer like this. I just wish I couldve identified it.

Hand bottle:  Courtesy of Eyedrinkale via trade.  Light aroma of yeast, banana, and grass.  Pours a cloudy orangish-yellow with a large off-white head with very good retention.  Great lacing.  Lightly yeasty up front with some hints of caramel.  Finishes with moderate floral hops and a peppery spiciness.

Pours a creamy dark caramel body that is foggy leaving a thin lace that is sudsy. The aroma is citrus, hoppy, sweet hard candy, very nice. The taste is slightly watery, but makes up for it with a malty caramel mouthfeel, followed by a massaging of hops to bring the taste to life. This is very drinkable, but overall not much going on in terms of complexity but that is what is meant of this style IMO.

Tap @ Dinosaur BBQ.  This beer was described as a lager.  Pours an amber with a quickly dissappating head.  Ther nose has fruit and malts.  There is a sweet mildness to this beer and then a bittering flavor, too much so for me, especially in the finish.  I did enjoy the upfront melding of softer flavors and it was fine.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2006 On tap, poured into pint glass.  A glowing orange color, translucent but cannot see through the beer.  Actually, one of the most beautiful shades of orange colored beer I have ever seen.  A creamy aroma with sweetness, slight fruitiness, and a hop presence but not overpowering.  Tastes like an IPA/cream ale to me with just a bit of bitterness at the end.  Medium-light body.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: The first time I had this beer, I wasnt impressed, but they must have changed the recipe somewhat and the end product was much more to my liking.  Im basing this rating on the draught I had on New Years Eve.  The oranginess was incredible, and it was very refreshing.  Hopped and very clean.  Sweet, yet a nice, dry finish.  The only thing is...I wouldnt call it a Belgian Ale at all now.  It seemed to be less spicy and much more fruity.  Yeasty?  Yes, yeasty.  Decent.

RBSG 2005.

Body is dark yellow.

Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain), moderately yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of banana and clove.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Light to medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation.

Typical American rendition of a Belgian - lots of banana/clove in the nose, on the sweet side.  Slightly off aftertaste and rather light/watery.

Hazy orange golden ale with a thin white head. Lightly diacetyl aroma with spicey malt notes. Stale. Rather bland malt with strong cardboard and light coriander notes. Blaaahhh! On tap at Blue Tusk, Summer 2005.

On tap at the Liberty Heights Tap Room, Redhook, Brooklyn, NY.  A Belgium-style blond ale having a hazy golden yellow hue. Soft carbonation. Small white diminishing head with good lacing.  Intoxicating hops, sweet malt, citrus, and fruity aromas.  Medium bodied that starts with a very fresh light sweet malt flavor with nice fruitiness and finishes with light hop bitterness. Well balanced.  An enjoyable excellent beer.
UPDATED: OCT 22, 2005 On tap.  Pours golden amber with decent white head.  Aroma is doughy and juicy.  Taste is pretty clean and herbal with a light dry finsh.

Color of watery tea, rafting seafoam head.  On tap, Peculier Pub, HHR trip. Vegetable green flavors over clear orange gel and hops.  Sort of like De Koninck with American and English hops.  Interesting.  Went a little flat on me.  Two-pronged finish - seems to finish fairly quickly, then the hops are resurrected in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2005 On draught at Publick House, 9/27/2005.  Pours a lucid, slightly hazy, honey yellow with slight, soft orange tints.  Head is small, but well retained and wispy, providing great lacing down the sides of the glass.  Aroma of clean, honeyish pils malt, soft sweet white dough, bits of lemons, tangerines, peaches and angel-food cake with a clean and light Belgian yeast presence.  Maybe a passing floral note of hops in the nose, but otherwise pretty light on those.  Flavor is pretty straightforward, very clean honey, light grainy pale malt, a bit more light peaches and a touch of sweet tangerines.  A bit of creaminess through the middle with a light Belgian yeastiness to follow, with light dough/malt sugars lingering on.  Very clean and wonderfully drinkable, with a low to moderate carbonation.  Hops keep the beer dry, without being terribly flavorful or noticeable, but thats fine with me.  A well-done piece of brewing, as seen by the clean nature, great balance and easy mouthfeel.  Surprised to see its 6.9abv.  Gets a little watery and loose in texture as it warms, with, perhaps, the malt getting a little boring at the end of the glass and some definite breadiness growing on the palate.
On tap at Redbones (Somerville, MA).  Golden coloured, well-balanced - had a little of everything in it.

Tap.  Hazy golden color with a large off-white head.  Malty aroma with some sweetness and touch of hops.  Flavors of caramel malt,  apricot and other fruits, and clovey spices.  Semi-dry with a light bitter finish.  Nice start for this place and would like to try the rest of the line up.

Highly effervescent deep orangey golden topped by a small white head. Buttery yeasty banana nose. Bready and fruity nature (peach, apricot) always in the sweetness department. Kinda ehavy on the butter this one. Sweet palate, coriander, bread and plenty of estery fruitiness play along joyfully. Soft palate, sweet and smooth with active yet easy going carbonation.

RBSG Growler
Fizzy, average sized head sits above a light golden body.
Mild candy aroma with some yeasty notes in the background.
Not overly impressive yet not offensive in any way. Lacks the overall complexity to grab my attention.

RBSG 05. Growler.  Its hard for this beer to recieve propper recognition when it is put up against the absolute best beers in the world like at the gathering, but it seemed that people were enjoying it nonetheless at the tasting friday night.  This is a really nice easy drinking belgian pale ale that is really well made.  It is quite unlike any other belgian pale ale I have ever had really.  Pours very light color- with slight haze- to almost clear, and a nice pure white fluffy head.  Aroma is bready and malty with a good amount of herbal and spicy hops.  Flavor is also pretty malty with a good amount of that traditional belgian spicy and fruity yeast with a nice hoppy backbone for bittering.  I really liked this one and I will definately get another growler for myself next time I go to Shoreline Beverage. (which Is where I got the original growler from).

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 2012-12-24. Hazy dark orange, small beige head. 3+ Modest aroma, hoppy with modest green leafy touches, sort of oily resiny quality. 7+ flavour is similar, oily resiny orange hops. Modest bitterness, lightly earthy malt undertones. 7+ average bodied palate is softly carbonated. Okay. 7/3/7/3/14 Can from Premier Gourment, Buffalo
RBSG 2005. Growler. Golden body, small white head. Sweet floral hops in the aroma. Mild bitterness, herbal floral hops, average palate. Meh. 5/3/5/3/12 2.8

Growler sampled at the RBSG 05 bottle tasting courtesy of Dickinsonbeer: Pours a clear bright golden with a thin, lightly-lacing white head.  Aroma is semi-sweet, lightly bready and mild.  Body mimics the aroma  with a touch of Belgian yeast and a little caramel maltiness and authenticity, but not much going on otherwise.
(Growler, RBSG05) Clear golden body with off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, herbal, some lemon.  Taste is medium sweet, herbal, some caramel, light lemon, fairly dry finish.  Light-medium body.
RBSG 2005: poured yellow orange with a medium white head. Light hoppy aroma. Flavor is mildly hoppy with a touch of banana. Light corn finish. Good.
(Bottle) Sampled at the RBSG 2005 in Montreal. Light amber, non-carbonated body with a white head. Fruity lager nose with a pine and kiwi flavour. Mild and bland.

2005 RBSG Montreal Friday Night Tasting. Growler. Pale golden colour with a frothy off-white head. Toasty citric, and honey aroma. Citrus, tasty, grainy, and light fruity flavours. Medium bodied, crisp mouthfeel.

This was on tap at Half Time in Poughkeepsie and its my favorite of the 3 on tap beers. Andy, brewer, explained it was a crossover beer which he hoped would knock stella rtois off some bars taps. This particular beer kicks stellas ass. It has a stella-like finish after-taste wise but is so much tastier as far as its breadiness lemony character.

Tap @ Barcade. Light gold with a full on fluffy white head and lots of lacing. A really nice looking beer. Floral hops and bready dough in the aroma. Body is low in carbonation in comparison to the head.. Taste has some nuttiness. Smooth and crisp. Shane rocks!

A pretty standard belgian golden ale - nothing is happening that is all that striking, but the brewers are showing that they can make a solid, true to style belgian, with a decent "flavor progression" - starts out lemony and spicy - gradually works in a really grainy, bready malt flavor - nice.
